words.def: A prefix meaning from, away from, or outside of.
words.name: ab-

words.def: The surface of an organ facing away from the axis; e.g. the lower surface of a lateral organ such as a leaf or petal.
words.name: abaxial

words.def: To abandon development of a structure or organ.
words.name: abort

words.def: shedding of an organ that is mature or aged, e.g. a ripe fruit or an old leaf.
words.name: abscission

words.def: a specialised layer of tissue formed, for example, at the base of a petiole or pedicel that allows the organ to be shed by abscission when it is ripe or senescent.
words.name: abscission zone

words.def: An adjective descriptive of a plant that has no apparent stem, or at least none visible above ground. Examples include some species of Agave, Oxalis and Attalea.[1]
words.name: acaulescent

words.def: Increasing in size with age, such as a calyx that continues to grow after the corolla has fallen, for example in Physalis peruviana.
words.name: accrescent

words.def: The suffix added to the stem of a generic name to form the name of a family.
words.name: -aceae

words.def: A dry 1-seeded indehiscent fruit; e.g. in the genus Ranunculus.
words.name: achene

words.def: Slender or needle-shaped.
words.name: acicular

words.def: Moving from roots to leaves, e.g. of molecular signals in plants.
words.name: acropetal

words.def: The regular leaves of a mature plant, produced above the base; usually in contrast to bathyphyll.
words.name: acrophyll

words.def: (describing a type of sorus) covering the entire abaxial surface of the frond, usually densely so, as in Elaphoglossum and Acrostichum.
words.name: acrostichoid

words.def: A prefix that indicates a radial form.
words.name: actino-

words.def: (leaf venation) palmate or radially arranged venation with three or more primary veins arising from at or near the base of the leaf, the primary veins reaching the margin or not.
words.name: actinodromous

words.def: regular; radially symmetrical; may be bisected into similar halves in at least two planes. Applies e.g. to steles and flowers in which the perianth segments within each whorl are alike in size and shape; compare regular; contrast with asymmetrical, irregular, zygomorphic.
words.name: actinomorphic

words.def: Armed with prickles; e.g. the stem of a rose.
words.name: aculeate

words.def: Tapering gradually to a point.
words.name: acuminate

words.def: Sharply pointed; converging edges making an angle of less than 90°; compare obtuse.
words.name: acute

words.def: A prefix meaning near or towards. Also meaning added to.
words.name: ad-

words.def: The surface of an organ facing towards the axis; e.g. the upper surface of a lateral organ such as a leaf or petal.
words.name: adaxial

words.def: grown or fused to an organ of a different kind, especially along a margin; e.g. a stamen fused to a petal; cf. connate.
words.name: adnate

words.def: A structure produced in an abnormal position; e.g. an adventitious bud produced from a stem rather than from the axil of a leaf.
words.name: adventitious

words.def: Introduced accidentally (usually referring to weeds).
words.name: adventive

words.def: Of the air; growing or borne above the surface of the ground.
words.name: aerial

words.def: The arrangement of sepals and petals or their lobes in an unexpanded flower bud; cf. vernation, the arrangement of leaves in a bud.
words.name: aestivation

words.def: With affinity to others, akin to; often used for a provisionally recognized but unnamed taxon considered close to that name, perhaps a hybrid or extreme variant.
words.name: aff. (affinis)

words.def: A cluster of fruits formed from the free carpels of one flower, e.g. blackberry; cf. multiple fruit.
words.name: aggregate fruit

words.def: see weed.
words.name: agricultural weed

words.def: having a wing or wings.
words.name: alate

words.def: an older name for the endosperm of flowering plants. Except for being a storage tissue for nutrients, it is not at all like the albumen (egg white) of animals.
words.name: albumen

words.def: (seeds) containing endosperm.
words.name: albuminous

words.def: Suffix to the stem of a generic name or descriptive name to indicate that it applies to a taxon of the rank of order.
words.name: -ales

words.def: a plant introduced to an area outside its natural range (foreign, exotic, non-native, non-indigenous).
words.name: alien

words.def: Molecule with a nitrogenous base, many used as drugs; e.g. morphine, quinine, strychnine.
words.name: alkaloid

words.def: (as adjective) leaves or flowers borne singly at different levels along a stem includes spiralled parts; or (as preposition) when something occurs between something else, for example stamens alternating with petals; compare opposite.
words.name: alternate

words.def: Synonym of catkin.
words.name: ament

words.def: When the ovule is bent so that both ends are near each other; cf. anatropous, campylotropous, orthotropous.
words.name: amphitropous

words.def: With the base dilated and clasping the stem, usually of leaves.
words.name: amplexicaul

words.def: When veins are joined by cross-veins to form a network.
words.name: anastomosing

words.def: When an ovule is inverted so that the micropyle faces the placenta (this is the most common ovule orientation in flowering plants); cf. amphitropous, campylotropous, orthotropous.
words.name: anatropous

words.def: Of plants, having bisexual flowers and male flowers on separate individuals; cf. andromonoecious, polygamodioecious, polygamomonoecious, polygamous.
words.name: androdioecious

words.def: of a species, with bisexual flowers and male flowers on the same plant; cf. gynomonoecious
words.name: andromonoecious

words.def: Male parts of flower; the stamens of a flower collectively; cf. gynoecium. Abbreviation: A. For instance A 3+3 indicates 6 stamens in two whorls.
words.name: androecium

words.def: A stalk bearing both the androecium and gynoecium of a flower above the level of insertion of the perianth.
words.name: androgynophore

words.def: With male and female flowers in the same inflorescence.
words.name: androgynous

words.def: having bisexual and male flowers on the same individual; cf. andromonoecious, polygamodioecious, polygamomonoecious, polygamous.
words.name: andromonoecious

words.def: Pollination by wind.
words.name: anemophily

words.def: flowering plants; plants with developing seeds enclosed in an ovary.
words.name: angiosperms

words.def: the condition of having a floral whorl with a different (usually smaller) number of parts from the other floral whorls.
words.name: anisomery

words.def: branching with branches having unequal diameters, such as a trunk and its branch, compare to isotomic.
words.name: anisotomic

words.def: A plant that completes its life cycle and dies within one year.
words.name: annual

words.def: branching then rejoining.
words.name: anastomose

words.def: positioned in front of, towards the apex, distal.
words.name: anterior

words.def: Pollen-bearing part of the stamen.
words.name: anther

words.def: 1.  (of a flower) the period during which pollen is presented and/or the stigma is receptive.
words.name: anthesis

words.def: Pointing up away from or perpendicular to a surface, cf. periclinal.
words.name: anticlinal

words.def: Directed towards or upwards, e.g. of hairs on a stem; cf. retrorse.
words.name: antrorse

words.def: Without petals.
words.name: apetalous

words.def: (plural apices) The tip; the point furthest from the point of attachment.
words.name: apex

words.def: (plural aphlebiae) Imperfect or irregular leaf endings commonly found on ferns and fossils of ferns from the Carboniferous Period.
words.name: aphlebia

words.def: (Usually referring to a leaf) terminating in a short sharp flexible point; less abrupt than mucronate.
words.name: apiculate

words.def: A form of pollination whereby pollen is distributed by honey bees.
words.name: apiphily

words.def: A prefix meaning away from, separate, without.
words.name: apo-

words.def: Of a gynoecium consisting with one or more carpels which are free from one another (or almost so); e.g. Ranunculaceae, Dilleniaceae.
words.name: apocarpous

words.def: Reproduction, where viable seed or spores are produced without fertilization. A plant produced in this way is an apomict.
words.name: apomixis

words.def: (in cladistics) a "different form" from the form of an ancestor, i.e., an innovation, of use in determining membership in a clade.
words.name: apomorphy

words.def: A secondary part attached to the main structure; an external growth that seldom has any obvious function.
words.name: appendage

words.def: Pressed closely, but not fused; e.g. leaves against a stem.
words.name: appressed

words.def: Plants whose natural habitat is water: living in or on water for all or a substantial part of the organism's life span, generally restricted to fresh or inland waters.
words.name: aquatic

words.def: Cobwebby, from being covered with fine white hairs.
words.name: arachnoid

words.def: Tree-like in growth or general appearance.
words.name: arborescent

words.def: (plural arboreta) A taxonomically arranged collection of trees.
words.name: arboretum

words.def: An non-native plant that has been present in a geographic area for some time; cf. neophyte.
words.name: archaeophyte

words.def: Having areoles, being composed of areoles, as an areolate crustose lichen.
words.name: areolate

words.def: (from areola) A space between the threads of a net; e.g. that part of a leaf surface defined by each of the elements of a vein network; as with cacti, the area between the veinlets of a leaf or the region of a cactus bearing the flowers and/or spines. In lichenology, an areole is a polygonal piece of a thallus surface when a crustose lichen it broken up like old dried and cracked paint, or like the polygonal "islands" of dried mud in a dry lake bed.
words.name: areole

words.def: (adjective arillate): A membranous or fleshy appendage (formed by expansion of the funicle) which partly or wholly covers a seed; e.g. the fleshy outer layer of lychee fruit and as found in Sapindaceae.
words.name: aril

words.def: With a stiff, bristle-like awn or tip.
words.name: aristate

words.def: A segment of a jointed stem or of a fruit with constrictions between the seeds; an organ part that separates easily from the rest of the organ at a joint or articulation.
words.name: article

words.def: Jointed; separating freely, leaving a clean scar; for example the fronds of certain ferns where they join the rhizome.
words.name: articulate

words.def: Spreading horizontally, then becoming erect.
words.name: ascending

words.def: The fruiting body (sporocarp) of an ascomycete fungus.
words.name: ascocarp

words.def: A member of the Ascomycota.
words.name: ascomycete

words.def: A division (biology) or phylum of fungi commonly called sac fungi. It is separated from the division Basidiomycota
words.name: Ascomycota

words.def: reproduction that does not involve gametes; i.e. vegetative reproduction.
words.name: asexual reproduction

words.def: irregular, unequal, lacking any plane of symmetry.
words.name: asymmetrical

words.def: Narrowing gradually.
words.name: attenuate

words.def: (adjective auriculate): Ear-shaped lobe.
words.name: auricle

words.def: Long, bristle-like appendage; e.g. terminating or on the back of glumes and/or lemmas of some grass spikelets.
words.name: awn

words.def: The upper angle between one part of a plant and another; e.g. the stem and a leaf.
words.name: axil

words.def: On an axis; of a placenta, on the central axis of the ovary.
words.name: axile

words.def: Borne in or arising from the axil of a leaf.
words.name: axillary

words.def: the main stem of a whole plant or inflorescence.
words.name: axis

words.def: rod-like, longer than wide, c.f. cylindrical
words.name: baculiform

words.def: a rear-facing point, as in a fish hook.
words.name: barb

words.def: with (barbs pointing in one direction.)
words.name: barbed

words.def: with barbed hairs (barbellae)
words.name: barbellate

words.def: the protective external layer of tissue on the stems and roots of trees and shrubs; includes all of the living and non-living tissue external to the cambium.
words.name: bark

words.def: at the base, situated or attached at the base.
words.name: basal

words.def: something attached by its base; e.g. an anther attached to the filament. compare: dorsifixed
words.name: basifixed

words.def: developing sequentially from the apex towards the base (i.e. with the youngest towards the base); e.g. of flowers in an inflorescence. Also, moving from leaves to roots, e.g. of molecular signals in plants.
words.name: basipetal

words.def: a specialized leaf that is produced at the base of a plant, usually when the plant is immature, and which serves to anchor the plant to a substrate; especially notable in the fern Teratophyllum. (compare: acrophyll).
words.name: bathyphyll

words.def: a prominent pointed terminal projection, especially of a carpel or fruit. adj. beaked
words.name: beak

words.def: an indehiscent fruit, with the seeds immersed in the pulp, for instance tomato.
words.name: berry

words.def: plant which completes its life cycle and dies within the second year; usually also forms a basal rosette of leaves the first year and flowers and fruits the second year.
words.name: biennial

words.def: forked; cut in two for about half its length. See also trifid.
words.name: bifid

words.def: having 2 leaflets (a type of compound leaf).
words.name: bifoliate

words.def: fusiform with a pinch in the middle
words.name: bifusiform

words.def: having two lips; e.g. the form of the petals in many irregular flowers.
words.name: bilabiate

words.def: arranged on opposite sides; e.g. leaves on a stem.
words.name: bilateral

words.def: having two loculi; e.g. in the anthers.
words.name: biloculate

words.def: making use of names consisting of two words to form the scientific name (or combination) in a Latin form. For example, where the first is the name of the genus to which the species belongs, and the second is the epithet given to that species to distinguish it from others in the same genus.
words.name: binomial

words.def: the system of nomenclature in which the scientific name of a species (and not of a taxon at any other rank) is a combination of two names, the first name being the generic name. The second name is referred to botanically as the specific epithet. Note that the two names constitute the species name, not just the second word.
words.name: binomial nomenclature

words.def: twice pinnate; for example of a compound leaf with individual leaflets pinnately divided.
words.name: bipinnate

words.def: a pinnatisect leaf with deeply dissected segments.
words.name: bipinnatisect

words.def: bearing both male and female reproductive organs; usually, flowers with both stamens and carpels; synonymous with hermaphrodite, synoecious, monoclinous. Bisexual flowers only occur on monoecious plants. See also androgynous, monoicous, and Plant reproductive morphology.
words.name: bisexual

words.def: (of an ovule), covered by two integuments.
words.name: bitegmic

words.def: ternate, with each division divided into three
words.name: biternate

words.def: having two valves or hinged parts. See also trivalve.
words.name: bivalve

words.def: the lamina or flattened part of a leaf, excluding the stalk.
words.name: blade

words.def: a fine white or bluish waxy powder occurring on plant parts, usually stems, leaves and fruits. It is easily removed by rubbing.
words.name: bloom

words.def: the trunk of a tree, usually below the lowest branch; cf. canopy.
words.name: bole

words.def: modified leaf associated with flower or inflorescence, differing in shape, size or colour from other leaves (and without an axillary bud).
words.name: bract

words.def: possessing bracts.
words.name: bracteate

words.def: small bracts borne singly or in pairs on the pedicel or calyx.
words.name: bracteole

words.def: possessing bracteoles (bractlets)
words.name: bracteolate

words.def: bracteole
words.name: bractlet

words.def: a small branch.
words.name: branchlet

words.def: a plant that loses all of its leaves briefly, so that it is leafless for, e.g., about two weeks.
words.name: brevideciduous

words.def: (adjective: bristly) straight stiff hair (smooth or with minute teeth) or upper part of an awn (when the latter is bent and has a lower, stouter, and usually twisted part, called the column).
words.name: bristle

words.def: pinnate leaf venation in which the secondary veins do not terminate at the leaf margin, but are joined in a succession of prominent arcs.
words.name: brochidodromous

words.def: informally, a collective term for mosses, hornworts and liverworts. Formally, these plants are placed in three separate divisions: hornworts (Anthocerophyta), liverworts (Marchantiophyta) and mosses (Bryophyta).
words.name: bryophyte

words.def: (adj. bulbiferous), thick storage organ, usually underground, consisting of a stem and leaf bases (the inner ones fleshy).
words.name: bulb

words.def: a bulb arising from another bulb.
words.name: bulbel

words.def: small deciduous bulb or tuber formed in the axil of a leaf or pinna; a means of vegetative propagation.
words.name: bulbil

words.def: a bulb arising from another bulb; a bulbil.
words.name: bulblet

words.def: surface with rounded or globular blisters.
words.name: bullate

words.def: loosely, a prickly fruit; a rough or prickly propagule consisting of a seed or fruit and associated floral parts or bracts.
words.name: burr

words.def: a root growing from the above-ground stem or trunk, and providing support, as in the case of Ficus macrophylla, the Moreton Bay fig.
words.name: buttress root

words.def: a growth form of a lichen thallus that is whispy, like teased wool.
words.name: byssoid

words.def: In lichenology, "C" is an abbreviation for the test result of placing 5% solution of calcium hypochlorite or sodium hypochlorite (e.g., household bleach without additives) on the cortex or the medulla of a lichen, to note the change in color, with no reaction noted as "C−", and production of a bright colour noted as "C+".
words.name: C, C−, C+

words.def: falling off early, for example the sepals of poppies, that fall off when the petals begin to open; compare persistent and fugacious.
words.name: caducous

words.def: tufted; e.g. the growth form of some grasses.
words.name: caespitose

words.def: A soil type that is rich in calcium carbonate. A lichen substrate rock type that is largely composed of calcium carbonate.
words.name: calcareous

words.def: callous, hardened, thickened.
words.name: callose

words.def: 1.  (plural: calli), a protruding mass of tissue.
words.name: callus

words.def: "calyx flowered", with petals and stamens attached to the calyx
words.name: calyciflorous

words.def: a leaf-like structure formed from a sepal or calyx lobe which enlarges, usually many-fold, before or after anthesis, especially when most of the sepals or calyx lobes retain their original size. More extreme than an accrescent calyx, calycophylls are found in Rubiaceae. cf. semaphyll, pterophyll.
words.name: calycophyll

words.def: having an epicalyx.
words.name: calyculate

words.def: (1) a cup-shaped structure formed from bracts, (2) in some Asteraceae, a circle of bracts below the involucre.
words.name: calyculus

words.def: a hood or lid; see operculum.
words.name: calyptra

words.def: (plural calyces) the outer whorl of a flower, usually green; the sepals of one flower collectively.
words.name: calyx

words.def: a tube formed by the fusion of the sepals (calyx), at least at the base.
words.name: calyx tube

words.def: bell-shaped.
words.name: campanulate

words.def: pinnate venation in which the secondary veins curve toward the margins, in some cases becoming nearly parallel with them, and not reconnecting with other veins to form loops.
words.name: camptodromous

words.def: when the ovule is oriented transversely (i.e. with its axis at right angles to its stalk) and with a curved embyro sac; cf. amphitropous, anatropous, orthotropous.
words.name: campylotropous

words.def: channelled; with a longitudinal groove.
words.name: canaliculate

words.def: approaching white in color, as in a leaf covered with white down or wool.
words.name: canescent

words.def: the branches and foliage of a tree; crown; cf. trunk. Also refers to the protective upper layer of a forest.
words.name: canopy

words.def: 1.  (noun) a tube, pore or passage with a narrow internal cross-section.
words.name: capillary

words.def: with knob-like head; of an inflorescence, with the flowers unstalked and aggregated into a dense cluster; of a stigma, like the head of a pin.
words.name: capitate

words.def: a dense cluster of sessile, or almost sessile, flowers or florets; e.g. a flower head in the daisy family Asteraceae. see pseudanthium and pseudanthium.
words.name: capitulum

words.def: a dry fruit formed from two of more united carpels and dehiscing when ripe (usually by splitting into pieces or opening at summit by teeth or pores).
words.name: capsule

words.def: (adjective carinate) see keel.
words.name: carina

words.def: a longitudinal cavity in the stems of Equisetum and extinct Equisetopsida, coinciding with a ridge in the stem surface.
words.name: carinal canal

words.def: the basic female reproductive organ in angiosperms, either consisting of a single sporophyll or a single locule of a compound ovary, with a style and a stigma. The gynoecium is the collective term for all of the carpels of a single flower.
words.name: carpel

words.def: hard and tough; gristly.
words.name: cartilaginous

words.def: a dry, indehiscent, one-seeded fruit in which the seed coat is closely fused to the fruit wall, as in most grasses.
words.name: caryopsis

words.def: a continuous band of suberin in the radial primary cell walls of the endodermis in vascular plant stems and roots that forms a permeability barrier to the passive diffusion of external water and solutes into the vascular tissue.
words.name: Casparian strip

words.def: a plant that appears with no apparent human assistance but does not develop a sustained population(s). Plants that persist only by new introductions; cf. alien.
words.name: casual alien

words.def: Early leaf forms of plants or shoots, such as cotyledons, bud-scales, rhizome-scales; anatomically they are leaves, but do not develop to perform the usual functions of photosynthetic leaves.
words.name: cataphyll

words.def: a spike, usually pendulous, in which the mostly small flowers are unisexual and without a conspicuous perianth; e.g. willows, poplars, oaks and casuarinas. The individual flowers often have scaly bracts; they are generally wind-pollinated. The catkins are usually shed as a unit.
words.name: catkin

words.def: having a narrow tail-like appendage or tip, e.g. a drip tip, cf. acuminate
words.name: caudate

words.def: Literally the stem of a plant, but also used to mean a rootstock, or particularly a basal stem structure or storage organ from which new growth arises. See also caudiciform
words.name: caudex (plural: caudices)

words.def: Literally meaning "stem-like" or "caudex-like", is sometimes used to mean "pachycaul", meaning "thick-stemmed".
words.name: caudiciform

words.def: borne on an aerial stem, e.g. leaves, flower or fruits (when applied to the latter two organs, usually referring to older stems; = cauliflorous).
words.name: cauline

words.def: 1.  basic (microscopic) unit of plant structure, generally consisting of compartments in a viscous fluid surrounded by a wall.
words.name: cell

words.def: of a two-branched organ attached by its centre, e.g. a hair, or anther.
words.name: centrifixed

words.def: alternative spelling of caespitose.
words.name: cespitose

words.def: with a papery texture.
words.name: chartaceous

words.def: cavity of an ovary.
words.name: chamber

words.def: sunken below the surface, resulting in a rounded channel.
words.name: channelled

words.def: of flowers that are pollinated when the perianth is open; cf. cleistogamous.
words.name: chasmogamous

words.def: an individual composed of two or more genetically different tissues, most commonly as a result of a graft and sometimes within the individual, by mutations and irregularities that occur during cell division.
words.name: chimera

words.def: pollinated by bats.
words.name: chiropterophilous

words.def: a green pigment in chloroplasts, essential for photosynthesis.
words.name: chlorophyll

words.def: an organelle present in plant cells that contains chlorophyll.
words.name: chloroplast

words.def: abnormal lack or paleness of color in a normally green organ.
words.name: chlorosis

words.def: (singular cilium, adjective ciliate) generally, hairs more or less confined to the margins of an organ, like eye-lashes; in motile cells, minute, hair-like protrusions which aid motility.
words.name: cilia

words.def: spirally coiled with the tip innermost; e.g. circinate vernation of the developing fronds of most ferns.
words.name: circinate

words.def: a photosynthetic stem, often leaf-like and usually with foliage leaves either absent or much reduced; cf. phyllode.
words.name: cladode

words.def: the principal category for taxa in a rank between division and order.
words.name: class

words.def: latticed or pierced with apertures, like a cage.
words.name: clathrate

words.def: club-shaped.
words.name: clavate

words.def: 1.  narrow, stalk-like basal portion of petal, sepal of bract.
words.name: claw

words.def: of flowers that self-pollinate and never open fully, or self-pollinate before opening; cf. chasmogamous.
words.name: cleistogamous

words.def: a plant growing more or less erect by leaning or twining on another structure for support, or by clinging with tendrils.
words.name: climber

words.def: (adjective clinal) continuous morphological variation in form within a species or sometimes between two species.
words.name: cline

words.def: plants derived from the vegetative reproduction of an individual, all having the same genetic constitution.
words.name: clone

words.def: plant parts fused or grown together to form a single unit.
words.name: coalescent

words.def: concave, spoon-shaped.
words.name: cochleariform

words.def: coiled like a snail's shell.
words.name: cochleate

words.def: An arranged colony of algae that acts like a single organism.
words.name: coenobium

words.def: A single cell with multiple nuclei, formed when nuclear division was not followed by cytokinesis.
words.name: coenocyte

words.def: A specialized tissue consisting of living cells with unevenly thickened cellulose and pectin cell walls that performs a support function in organs such as leaves and young stems that are composed of primary plant tissues.
words.name: collenchyma

words.def: a multicellular, glandular hair that usually produces a mucilaginous substance and is located on sepals, stipules, or petioles, or on nearby parts of stems; commonly found on plants in the order Gentianales.
words.name: colleter

words.def: in flowering plants, the central axis of the cone or fruit, e.g. in Callitris.
words.name: columella

words.def: 1.  structure extending above ovary and incorporating the style and stamens; gynostemium; e.g. in orchids.
words.name: column

words.def: shaped like a column.
words.name: columnar

words.def: a name often of no botanical standing and not governed by the ICNCP. The term generally applies to names such as Trademark Names, names covered by Plant Breeders Rights, Patents and Promotional Names; often used to enhance the sale of a plant.
words.name: commercial name

words.def: the seam or face at which two carpels adhere.
words.name: commissure

words.def: an assemblage, in nature, of plants that characteristically occur together.
words.name: community

words.def: composed of several parts, for instance a leaf with leaflets, a gynoecium with several carpels, or an inflorescence made up of smaller inflorescences.
words.name: compound

words.def: a compound palmate leaf has leaflets that radiate from a central point (usually at the top of a petiole), like spread-out fingers radiating from the palm of a hand.
words.name: compound palmate

words.def: flattened lengthwise, either laterally (from side to side) or dorsally (from front to back).
words.name: compressed

words.def: the same colour throughout, uniformy coloured.
words.name: concolorous

words.def: two sides of a flat surface are folded along the midline to face each other. See also ptyxis, aestivation, and vernation.
words.name: conduplicate

words.def: a fruit, usually woody, ovoid to globular, including scales, bracts or bracteoles arranged around a central axis, e.g. in gymnosperms, especially conifers and Casuarina.
words.name: cone

words.def: of an inflorescence when the overall structure substantially differs from that of the individual branches of the inflorescence, a rarely used term; e.g. the bottlebrush multiple-flower head of Callistemons.
words.name: conflorescence

words.def: fused to another organ (or organs) of the same kind; e.g. petals in a corolla tube; cf. adnate.
words.name: connate

words.def: the part of an anther that connects the anther cells.
words.name: connective

words.def: coming into contact or converging.
words.name: connivent

words.def: belonging to the same species.
words.name: conspecific

words.def: adjoining, touching, but not united.
words.name: contiguous

words.def: (sepals and petals) a type of imbricate aestivation in which one side of each segment overlaps one of the adjacent segments and the other side is overlapped by the other adjacent segment. see: convolute
words.name: contort

words.def: twisted out of the normal shape.
words.name: contorted

words.def: 1. referring to the arrangement of floral or foliar organs in a bud when each organ or segment has one edge overlapping the adjacent organ or segment; a form of imbricate arrangement; contort.
words.name: convolute

words.def: heart-shaped, with the notch lowermost; of the base of a leaf, like the notched part of a heart.
words.name: cordate

words.def: leathery; stiff and tough, but somewhat flexible.
words.name: coriaceous

words.def: fleshy, swollen stem base, usually underground, storing food reserves, with buds naked or covered by very thin scales; a type of rootstock. Adjectives derived from "corm" include "cormose" and "cormous".
words.name: corm

words.def: collective term for the petals of a flower.
words.name: corolla

words.def:
(adjective: coronate) literally, crown
1. in flowering plants, ring of structures that may be united in a tube, arising from the corolla or perianth of a flower and standing between the perianth lobes and the stamens. The trumpet of a daffodil is a corona.
words.name: corona

words.def: On a lichen, the cortex is the "skin", or outer layer of thallus tissue that covers the medulla Fruticose lichens have one cortex encircling the branches, even flattened, leaf-like forms; foliose lichens have different upper and lower cortices; crustose, placodioid and squamulose lichens have an upper cortex but no lower cortex; and leprose lichens lack any cortex.
words.name: cortex

words.def: Growing on bark (compare with lignicolous, growing on wood with the bark stripped off.)
words.name: corticolous

words.def: (adjective corymbose) inflorescence with branches arising at different points but reaching about the same height, giving the flower cluster a flat-topped appearance.
words.name: corymb

words.def: (adjective costate) a rib.
words.name: costa

words.def: a costapalmate leaf has a definite costa (midrib), unlike the typical palmate or fan leaf, but the leaflets are arranged radially like in a palmate leaf.
words.name: costapalmate

words.def: primary leaf or leaves of an embryo, becoming the seed leaf or leaves.
words.name: cotyledon

words.def: pinnate venation in which the secondary veins terminate at the margins, often as teeth.
words.name: craspedodromous

words.def: In the shape of a saucer or shallow cup; hemispherical or more shallow .
words.name: crateriform

words.def: with blunt or rounded teeth, scalloped.
words.name: crenate

words.def: minutely scalloped.
words.name: crenulate

words.def: finely curled. A term generally applied to the edges of leaves and petals.
words.name: crisped

words.def: a sclereid which contains a druse and has the lignin deposited excentrically on the cell wall to form a cup shape, or in cross section, a ∪-shape.
words.name: cristarque cell

words.def: see canopy.
words.name: crown

words.def: to make something interbreed; the act of hybridization.
words.name: cross

words.def: cross-shaped.
words.name: cruciform

words.def: hard, thin and brittle.
words.name: crustaceous

words.def: forming a closely applied surface layer, forming a crust
words.name: crustose

words.def: ferns, bryophytes, algae and fungi (including lichenized fungi); 'lower plants'; plants producing spores, and without stamens, ovaries or seeds, literally plants whose sexual reproductive organs are not conspicuous cf. phanerogam.
words.name: cryptogams

words.def: from Latin cucullus, a hood. Hood-like or hooded, commonly referring to the shape of leaves or petals. (Example: Pelargonium cucullatum). Similarly derived terms include cuculliform and cuccularis.
words.name: cucullate

words.def: in grasses, sedges, rushes, and some other monocotyledons, an aerial stem bearing the inflorescence; strictly, from the base of the plant to the lowest involucral bract (or base of the inflorescence).
words.name: culm

words.def: a plant whose origin or selection is primarily due to intentional human activity.
words.name: cultigen

words.def: the term cultivar is derived from cultivated variety and denotes an assemblage of cultivated plants clearly distinguished by one or more characters (morphological, physiological, cytological, chemical or other); when reproduced (sexually or asexually), the assemblage retains its distinguishing characters. A cultivar may arise in cultivation or be introduced from the wild. It is a variant of horticultural interest or value. Cultivar names are written with single quotation marks around them e.g. 'Blue Carpet', 'Alba'. All new names established after 1 January 1959, must be in common language (that is, not in Latin) but names established in Latin prior to this date are retained in Latin form.
words.name: cultivar

words.def: the defining part of a name that denominates a cultivar. Cultivars are designated by fancy (q.v.) epithets appended either to the scientific name or to the common name of the taxon to which they belong; they are not italicized but placed in single quotation marks, for example Rubus nitidoides 'Merton Early'. 'Merton Early' is the cultivar epithet.
words.name: cultivar epithet

words.def: wedge-shaped; with straight sides converging at base. See Leaf shape.
words.name: cuneate

words.def: a cup-shaped structure composed of coalescent bracts, such as the cup of an acorn.
words.name: cupule

words.def: shaped like a cupule.
words.name: cupular

words.def: bearing cupules.
words.name: cupulate

words.def: nearly hemispherical, shaped like a cupola or dome.
words.name: cupuliform

words.def: tipped with a cusp.
words.name: cuspidate

words.def: a waterproofing layer covering the epidermis of aerial plant surfaces, composed of the polymers cutin, and/or cutan and waxes.
words.name: cuticle

words.def: a piece of plant, usually an apical tip of shoot structure but may be root or leaf, cut from plant and used for vegetative propagation.
words.name: cutting

words.def: plural of cyathium
words.name: cyathia

words.def: an inflorescence of unisexual flowers surrounded by involucral bracts, esp. the flowers of Euphorbia.
words.name: cyathium

words.def: The bract-like structure of a Euphorbia on which the involucre sits, usually but not always occurring in twos. They may sometimes be brightly colored and confused with petals.
words.name: cyathophyll

words.def: rod-like and 2-3 times as long as wide, c.f. baculiform.
words.name: cylindrical

words.def: (adjective cymose) inflorescence in which the main axis and all lateral branches end in a flower (each lateral may be repeatedly branched).
words.name: cyme

words.def: a dry, indehiscent, one-seeded fruit formed from an inferior ovary.
words.name: cypsela

words.def: falling seasonally, for instance bark, leaves, petals; compare persistent.
words.name: deciduous

words.def: curving downwards, and then upwards at the tip. May be qualified, e.g. declinate-ascendant
words.name: declinate

words.def: divided to more than one level, as in bipinnate leaves for example, in which the leaflets of what otherwise would be a pinnate leaf, are themselves pinnately divided
words.name: decompound

words.def: to shed or peel off the outer bark of a tree.
words.name: decorticate

words.def: with branches growing horizontally on the ground, but turned up at the ends.
words.name: decumbent

words.def: extending downwards beyond the point of insertion e.g. when the base of a leaf or a fungal gill is prolonged downwards along the stem in a raised line or narrow wing.
words.name: decurrent

words.def: = decussate. The usage decussant is questionable and occurs rarely, probably as an error. The formally correct usage is decussate.
words.name: decussant

words.def: opposite, with successive pairs borne at right angles to the last; generally applied to the arrangement of leaves.
words.name: decussate

words.def: of a constant number; e.g. twice as many stamens as the petals or sepals (or less), or an inflorescence ending in a flower or an aborted floral bud, typically a cymose inflorescence; cf. indefinite.
words.name: definite

words.def: bent downwards; compare inflexed.
words.name: deflexed

words.def: breaking open at maturity to release contents. Refers e.g. to the opening of fruits to release the seeds, of anthers to release the pollen and sporangia to release the spores. Contrast with indehiscent
words.name: dehiscent

words.def: with the shape of the uppercase Greek letter Δ, i.e. like a more or less equilateral triangle. See Leaf shape.
words.name: deltoid

words.def: tree-like, branching like a tree.
words.name: dendroid

words.def: toothed. See Leaf margin.
words.name: dentate

words.def: finely toothed, a diminutive form of dentate.
words.name: denticulate

words.def: inhabiting a desert.
words.name: deserticolous

words.def: limited, usually in growth.
words.name: determinate

words.def: A reproductive part of a plant, adapted for dispersal and for establishing new plants; a disseminule such as a seed, or specialised buds, branches, inflorescences or fruits.
words.name: diaspore

words.def: a cymose inflorescence with all branches below the terminal flower in regular opposite pairs; compare monochasium.
words.name: dichasium

words.def: perianth is divided into separate calyx and corolla. Compare to homochlamydeous, in which they are indistinguishable
words.name: dichlamydeous

words.def: forking into two equal branches. This may result from an equal division of the growing tip, or may be sympodial, in which the growing tip is aborted and replaced. Typically refers to mode of branch growth, as in Aloe dichotoma, but also to other organs, such as the thorns of various species of Carissa (which morphologically are branches) and thalli or hyphae of various algae and fungi.
words.name: dichotomous

words.def: a flowering plant whose embryo has two (rarely more) cotyledons (seed leaves) (common usage: dicot.) compare monocotyledon (common usage: monocot.).
words.name: dicotyledon

words.def: with segments spreading from a common centre, like the fingers of a hand; see also palmate, palmatisect.
words.name: digitate

words.def: of vascular plants, when male and female reproductive structures develop on different individuals. cf. monoecious.
words.name: dioecious

words.def: of bryophyte gametophytes, when male and female reproductive structures develop on different individuals. cf. monoicous.
words.name: dioicous

words.def: with two full sets of chromosomes in the nucleus of a sporophyte cell, that is one set from each of the parental gametes. This is expressed symbolically as 2n, where n = the number of chromosomes in the haploid gametes.
words.name: diploid

words.def: stamens arranged in two whorls, with the outer whorl alternating with the petals, while the inner whorl is opposite the petals. Compare: obdiplostemonous.
words.name: diplostemonous

words.def: a plate or ring of structures derived from the receptacle, and occurring between whorls of floral parts. In some groups, especially Sapindales, the nectary is in the form of a prominent disk. In daisies, the central part of the capitulum is a disk, hence flowers borne there are called disk flowers or florets.
words.name: disk (disc)

words.def: resembling a disc or plate, having both thickness and parallel faces and with a rounded margin. Also used to describe the flower head of Asteraceae where there are no ray florets, but only disc florets.
words.name: discoid

words.def: of leaves, with upper and lower surfaces of a different colour.
words.name: discolorous

words.def: occurring in widely separated geographic areas, distinctly separate; applies to a discontinuous range in which one or more populations are separated from other potentially interbreeding populations far enough as to preclude gene flow between them.
words.name: disjunct

words.def: deeply divided; cut into many segments.
words.name: dissected

words.def: remote from the point of origin or attachment; the free end; cf. proximal.
words.name: distal

words.def: arranged in two opposite rows (and hence in the same plane).
words.name: distichous

words.def: separate or free, not united.
words.name: distinct

words.def: the condition in which the flowers of a species occur in two forms that differ only by the length of the style and stamens, and flowers of only one of these forms appear on any one plant. see:heterostyly
words.name: distyly

words.def: of the day; occurring or opening in the daytime.
words.name: diurnal

words.def: wide-spreading.
words.name: divaricate

words.def: spreading in different directions, generally upward.
words.name: divergent

words.def: the term used for the rank below kingdom in the taxonomic hierarchy.
words.name: division

words.def: (singular domatium) Any hollow structure formed by a plant that is inhabited by animals such as ants or mites.
words.name: domatia

words.def: at the rear or back, facing away from the axis (abaxial) in a lateral organ or away from the substrate in a prostrate plant.
words.name: dorsal

words.def: attached at or by the back, e.g. anthers on a filament.
words.name: dorsifixed

words.def: having structurally different upper and lower surfaces, e.g. some leaves.
words.name: dorsiventral

words.def: a long, narrow, caudate or acuminate extension at the tip of a leaf or leaflet.
words.name: drip tip

words.def: a succulent fruit formed from one carpel; the single seed is enclosed by a stony layer of the fruit wall; kernel; e.g. peaches, olives.
words.name: drupe

words.def: a drupe, usually small, formed from one of the carpels in an apocarpous flower. Drupelets usually form a compound fruit, as in Rubus, but they may become widely separated, as in Ochna.
words.name: drupelet

words.def: a globular mass of calcium oxalate crystals, usually with the crystals radiating from an organic core.
words.name: druse

words.def: The suffix added to the stem of a generic name to form the name of a tribe: for instance, Aster → Astereae.
words.name: -eae

words.def: without bracts. Similarly ebracteolate.
words.name: ebracteate

words.def: the range of environmental conditions in which an organism can survive.
words.name: ecological amplitude

words.def: Influenced by or of the soil.
words.name: edaphic

words.def: oily body attached to the seed.
words.name: elaiosome

words.def: a form of pollination whereby pollen or spores are distributed by the feet of elephants, as in Rafflesia arnoldii
words.name: elephophily

words.def: a 3-dimensional shape, elliptical in all sections through the long-axis.
words.name: ellipsoid

words.def: planar, shaped like a flattened circle, symmetrical about both the long and the short axis, tapering equally both to the tip and the base; oval.
words.name: elliptical (elliptic)

words.def: notched at apex (notch usually broad and shallow).
words.name: emarginate

words.def: young plant contained by a seed.
words.name: embryo

words.def: a plant taller than the surrounding vegetation or, for a water-based plant, one whose leaves and flowers are above the water.
words.name: emergent

words.def: the condition in which the gynoecium protrudes laterally, to the right (dextrostyly) or to the left (sinistrostyly) of the androecium. example: Senna.
words.name: enantiostyly

words.def: having a natural distribution restricted to a particular geographic region; cf. native.
words.name: endemic

words.def: the innermost layer of the wall of a fruit; in a drupe, the stony layer surrounding the seed.
words.name: endocarp

words.def: the innermost layer of the cortex of vascular plant roots, also present in the stems of pteridophytes. The radial walls are impregnated with suberin to form a permeability barrier known as the Casparian strip.
words.name: endodermis

words.def: endophloic
words.name: endophloeodal

words.def: (synonym – endophloeodal) of crustose lichens, having the thallus growing within rather than on the bark of trees,[2]:159 Compare with epiphloedal or corticolous growing on the surface wood or bark; also cf. endolithic growing within rock, not wood
words.name: endophloic

words.def: 1.  (angiosperms) a nutritive tissue surrounding the embryo of the seed, usually triploid, originating from the fusion of both polar nuclei with one gamete after the fertilization of the egg.
words.name: endosperm

words.def: shaped like the blade of a sword.
words.name: ensiform

words.def: 1.  not divided.
words.name: entire

words.def: a form of pollination whereby pollen or spores are distributed by insects.
words.name: entomophily

words.def: short-lived. See also caducous.
words.name: ephemeral

words.def: an involucre resembling an outer calyx; e.g. as seen in Hibiscus.
words.name: epicalyx

words.def: the outer layer of the wall of a fruit, i.e. the 'skin'.
words.name: epicarp

words.def: said of buds shoots or flowers developing from the old wood of trees, especially after injury or fire.
words.name: epicormic

words.def: the part of the plant axis or stem between the cotyledonary node and first foliage leaves.
words.name: epicotyl

words.def: a layer of crystalline or amorphous wax deposited on the surface of the plant cuticle.
words.name: epicuticular wax

words.def: an organ's outermost layer of cells, usually only one cell thick.
words.name: epidermis

words.def: borne on the ovary; describes floral parts when attached above the level of the ovary and arising from tissue fused to the ovary wall; cf. hypogynous, perigynous.
words.name: epigynous

words.def: growing on stone; compare lithophytic, a plant growing on stone.
words.name: epilithic

words.def: Dead tissue (necral) above the surface of the cortex of a lichen.
words.name: epinecral

words.def: of stamens that are attached to the petals.
words.name: epipetalous

words.def: Growing on bark; cf. endophloedal - growing inside, not on, the bark; cf. epilithic - growing on rock, not bark.
words.name: epiphloedal

words.def: Living on the surface of a plant; cf. lithophytic.
words.name: epiphytic

words.def: of stamens that are attached to the tepals.
words.name: epitepalous

words.def: (adjective epiphytic) one plant growing on another without deriving nourishment from it (in other words, not parasitic); compare parasite. Loosely, and incorrectly, applied to plants that are not terrestrial (they may grown on various inorganic or organic surfaces), and often to orchids, which are rock-dwelling (and therefore strictly lithophytic).
words.name: epiphyte

words.def: the adjectival component in a binomial; final word or combination of words in a name of more than one word (other than a term denoting rank) that denominates an individual taxon.
words.name: epithet

words.def: Seed dispersal by sticking on the outside of vertebrate animals.
words.name: epizoochory

words.def: not pruinose
words.name: epruinose

words.def: of a leaf when folded lengthwise and clasping another leaf.
words.name: equitant

words.def: upright, more or less perpendicular to the ground or point of attachment. Compare patent (spreading). Erecto-patent, between erect and patent.
words.name: erect

words.def: with leaves like those of the European heaths (Erica), small and sharply pointed.
words.name: ericoid

words.def: with the margin irregular as though nibbled or worn away.
words.name: erose

words.def: having an even number of leaflets in a compound leaf, = paripinnate.
words.name: even-pinnate

words.def: not deciduous, having leaves all the year round.
words.name: evergreen

words.def: in nomenclature, indicating that the preceding author proposed the name but did not legitimately publish it, and that the succeeding author referred to the first author when legitimately publishing the name. See Author citation (botany).
words.name: ex

words.def: the outer layer of the pericarp, often the skin of fleshy fruits.
words.name: exocarp

words.def: the outer layer of the testa (seed coat). It is derived from the outer integument of the ovule.
words.name: exotesta

words.def: not native; introduced from another region or country.
words.name: exotic

words.def: projected beyond, e.g. the stamens beyond the corolla tube.
words.name: exserted

words.def: without stipules.
words.name: exstipulate

words.def: outside the stamens or androecium, usually referring to the location of a nectary disk.
words.name: extrastaminal

words.def: of anther locules, opening towards the outside of the flower; cf. introrse, latrorse.
words.name: extrorse

words.def: a single cross; a plant breeding term for the result of a repeatable cross between two pure bred lines.
words.name: F1 hybrid

words.def: a plant breeding term for the result of a plant arising from a cross between two F1 hybrids; may also refer to self-pollination in a population of F1 hybrids.
words.name: F2 hybrid

words.def: shaped like a kidney-bean.
words.name: fabiform

words.def: of parasites, optional; compare obligate.
words.name: facultative

words.def: curved like the blade of a scythe.
words.name: falcate

words.def: a formal group of one or more genera with features and/or ancestry in common; the term for the principal rank between order and genus.
words.name: family

words.def: powderiness that is mealy
words.name: farinaceous

words.def: (adjective fasciculate) cluster, e.g. a tuft of leaves all arising from the same node.
words.name: fascicle

words.def: branching in a cluster like a bundle of sticks or needles, having fascicles.
words.name: fasciculate

words.def: honeycombed. With regular, angled pits. Compare foveolate.
words.name: faveolate

words.def: pertaining to the fauces; located in the throat of a calyx or corolla.
words.name: faucal

words.def: the throat of a calyx or corolla; the conspicuously widened portion between the mouth and the apex of the tube. In Boraginaceae, the site of distinctive appendages.
words.name: fauces

words.def: covered with very dense, interlocked and matted hairs with the appearance or texture of felt or woollen cloth.
words.name: felted

words.def: with translucent areas. See also perforate, with holes.
words.name: fenestrate

words.def: rust-colored.
words.name: ferruginous

words.def: capable of producing fruit; of flowers when they produce seed or of anthers containing pollen.
words.name: fertile

words.def: union of male and female gametes.
words.name: fertilization

words.def: 1.  a fiber cell.
words.name: fiber

words.def: a type of cell that is found in sclerenchyma, it is much elongated and dies soon after an extensive modification of its cell wall. The cell wall is usually thickly lignified, but is sometimes gelatinous.
words.name: fiber cell

words.def: 1.  stalk of a stamen
words.name: filament

words.def: consisting of filaments or fibres, hairlike.
words.name: filamentous

words.def: thread-like. e.g. stamen filaments, or leaf shapes.
words.name: filiform

words.def: slender hair-like process (plural: fimbriae)
words.name: fimbria

words.def: fringed.
words.name: fimbriate

words.def: a split or crack, often referring to fissured bark. also, a line or opening of dehiscence.
words.name: fissure

words.def: A tube-shaped cavity.
words.name: fistule

words.def: Hollow, usually applied to a tube-shaped cavity as in a reed.
words.name: fistulose

words.def: fan-shaped.
words.name: flabellate

words.def: limp; tending to wilt; compare turgid.
words.name: flaccid

words.def: bent alternately in different directions; zig-zag.
words.name: flexuous (flexuose)

words.def: with a soft and woolly covering of hairs.
words.name: floccose

words.def: 1.  all the plants growing in a certain region or country.
words.name: flora

words.def: See perianth.
words.name: floral envelope

words.def: the upper leaves at the base of the flowering branches.
words.name: floral leaves

words.def: graphical means to describe the flower structure, a schematic cross-section through a young flower.
words.name: floral diagram

words.def: textual means to describe the flower structure using numbers, letters and various symbols.
words.name: floral formula

words.def: an imprecise term sometimes used as a synonym of hypanthium or of corolla tube or of calyx tube.
words.name: floral tube

words.def: literally a small flower, but usually refers to the individual true flowers clustered within an inflorescence, particularly in inflorescences of the daisy and grass families.
words.name: floret

words.def: the sexual reproductive structure of the Angiosperms, typically with a gynoecium, androecium, perianth and an axis.
words.name: flower

words.def: preceded by a number: having a certain number of leaflets; for example, 3-foliate, "having three leaflets"
words.name: foliate

words.def: growth habit of certain lichens, algae, and fungi that prefer to grow on the leaves of vascular plants.
words.name: foliicolous

words.def: a dry fruit formed from one carpel, splitting along a single suture, to which the seeds are attached; cf. pod (of legume).
words.name: follicle

words.def: a small leaf-like appendage on the front or back.
words.name: foliole

words.def: leaflike, flattened like a leaf
words.name: foliose

words.def: any non-woody flowering plant that is not a grass, sedge, or rush.
words.name: forb

words.def: vegetation dominated by trees with single trunks (including closely arranged trees with or without an understorey of shrubs and herbs).
words.name: forest

words.def: a taxonomic category subordinate to species and within the taxonomic hierarchy, below variety (varietas), usually differentiated by a minor character.
words.name: forma (in common usage, form)

words.def: with regular tiny pits. Compare faveolate.
words.name: foveolate

words.def: not united with others organs of the same type; not attached at one end.
words.name: free

words.def: of placentation, ovules attached to a free-standing column in the centre of a unilocular ovary.
words.name: free central

words.def: a leaf of a fern, cycad or palm.
words.name: frond

words.def: shrub-like (fruticose) or becoming shrub-like
words.name: frutescent

words.def: shrubby, with the branching character of a shrub
words.name: fruticose

words.def: seed-bearing structure in angiosperms formed from the ovary, and sometimes associated floral parts, after flowering.
words.name: fruit

words.def: disappearing, falling off, or withering; compare persistent and caducous.
words.name: fugacious

words.def: the stalk of an ovule.
words.name: funicle (funiculus)

words.def: with a form gradually widening from the base to apex; funnel-shaped.
words.name: funnelform

words.def: forked, usually applied to a terminal division; with two long lobes.
words.name: furcate

words.def: joined together.
words.name: fused

words.def: rod-shaped and narrowing gradually from the middle towards each end; spindle-shaped.
words.name: fusiform

words.def: (in gymnosperms) a fleshy cone (megastrobilus); chiefly relates to those borne by junipers and cypresses and often mistakenly called berries.
words.name: galbulus

words.def: a cell or nucleus that fuses with another of the opposite sex in sexual reproduction.
words.name: gamete

words.def: the haploid multicellular phase in the alternation of generations of plants and algae that bears gametes. In bryophytes the gametophyte is the dominant vegetative phase; in ferns and their allies it is a small free-living plant known as the prothallus; in gymnosperms and angiosperms the gametophytes are reduced to microscopic structures dependent on the sporophyte, male gametophytes contained in pollen grains and females contained within the ovules.
words.name: gametophyte

words.def: the range of genetic variation found in a population.
words.name: gene pool

words.def: (plural genera) a group of one or more species with features or ancestry (or both) in common. Genus is the principal category of taxa intermediate in rank between family and species in the nomenclatural hierarchy.
words.name: genus

words.def: the name of a genus, for example Acacia, Eucalyptus.
words.name: generic name

words.def: the genetic make-up of an individual.
words.name: genotype

words.def: 1.  of seeds, describing the complex sequence of physiological and structural changes that occur from resting to growth stage.
words.name: germination

words.def: when part of an organ is swollen; usually with a pouch-like enlargement at base.
words.name: gibbous (gibbose)

words.def: becoming glabrous, almost glabrous.
words.name: glabrescent

words.def: without surface ornamentation such as hairs, scales or bristles; (in lichenology) having no indumentum.
words.name: glabrous

words.def: a secretory structure within or on the surface of a plant.
words.name: gland

words.def: hairs tipped with a gland.
words.name: glandular hair

words.def: with a whitish bloom, blue-green in colour; e.g. the surface of the young leaves of many eucalypts.
words.name: glaucous

words.def: spherical. See also subglobose.
words.name: globose (globular)

words.def: approximately spherical.
words.name: globulose

words.def: a barbed hair or bristle, e.g. the fine hairs in Opuntia.
words.name: glochid

words.def: bracts subtending the floret(s) of a sedge, or similar plant; in grasses forming the lowermost organs of a spikelet (there are usually 2 but 1 is sometimes reduced; or rarely, both are absent).
words.name: glumes

words.def: sticky.
words.name: glutinous

words.def: 1.  of a plant, the artificial union of plant parts.
words.name: graft

words.def: a taxon whose members consist of tissue from two or more different plants in intimate association originated by grafting. The addition sign "+" is used to indicate a graft-chimaera either as a part of a formula (e.g. Crataegus monogyna + Mespilus germanica), or in front of an abbreviated name (e.g. +Crataegomespilus 'Dardari'). The nomenclature of graft hybrids is governed by the International Code of Nomenclature for Cultivated Plants.
words.name: graft chimaera (sometimes graft hybrid)

words.def: of a surface, covered with small rounded protuberances.
words.name: granular

words.def: a plant belonging to the family Poaceae.
words.name: grass

words.def: low vegetation dominated by grasses.
words.name: grassland

words.def: 1.  of dense vegetation that covers the ground.
words.name: groundcover

words.def:
a formal category equivalent to or below the rank of genus. It distinguishes:
1. an assemblage of two or more cultivars within a species or hybrid.
words.name: Group

words.def: each of the two cells that surround the stoma and control gas exchange between the apoplast of the plant and the external air.
words.name: guard cell

words.def: with droplet-shaped spots. Compare punctate, maculate.
words.name: guttate, guttatus

words.def: the secretion of liquid water from uninjured plant parts. See hydathode.
words.name: guttation

words.def: with or appearing to be spotted with oil droplets; (of spores) having oil droplets inside
words.name: guttulate

words.def: a seed-bearing plant with unenclosed ovules borne on the surface of a sporophyll; includes, among others, conifers, Ginkgo, Gnetum and cycads. From gymno = naked, exposed; compare angio = covered, enclosed.
words.name: gymnosperm

words.def: of a style, arising near the base of the gynoecium, e.g. between the lobes of the ovary.
words.name: gynobasic

words.def: of a species, with some plants bearing only bisexual flowers and others bearing only female flowers.
words.name: gynodioecious

words.def: of a species, with bisexual flowers and female flowers on the same plant.
words.name: gynomonoecious

words.def: female parts of flower; the collective term for the carpels of a flower whether united or free; cf. pistil; androecium. Abbreviation: G. For instance G indicating superior ovary. G(5) indicates having 5 fused carpels.
words.name: gynoecium

words.def: stalk supporting the gynoecium (above the level of insertion of the other floral parts).
words.name: gynophore

words.def: the general external appearance of a plant, including size, shape, texture and orientation.
words.name: habit

words.def: the place where a plant lives; the environmental conditions of its home.
words.name: habitat

words.def: a flat attachment that forms when the thallus of a fruticose or foliose lichens comes in contact with a substrate, different from rhizines and hapters.
words.name: hafter

words.def: a single elongated cell or row of cells borne on the surface of an organ.
words.name: hair

words.def: of ovary, partly below and partly above the level of attachment of the other floral parts; compare inferior, superior.
words.name: half-inferior

words.def: having a transparent coating, or being of a spores outer layer.
words.name: halonate

words.def: a plant adapted to living in highly saline habitats; a plant that accumulates high concentrations of salt in its tissues.
words.name: halophyte

words.def: the controlled act of pollination that excludes the possibility of open-pollination.
words.name: hand-pollination

words.def: with one set of chromosomes, e.g. the complement of chromosomes in each of the cells of the gametophyte, the nucleus of a gamete and the spores. This is expressed symbolically as n, where n = the gamete number of chromosomes.
words.name: haploid

words.def: an attachment that may form when a foliose lichen thallus comes in contact with a substrate.
words.name: hapter

words.def: triangular in outline, the basal lobes pointing outwards, so that the base appears truncate; may refer only to the base of a leaf with such lobes; cf. sagittate which refers to basal lobes pointing backwards.
words.name: hastate

words.def: in parasitic plants, a structure developed for penetrating the host's tissues.
words.name: haustorium

words.def: see capitulum, a pseudanthium.
words.name: head

words.def: vegetation dominated by small shrubs which usually have ericoid leaves.
words.name: heathland

words.def: coiled; of a cymose inflorescence, when the branching is repeatedly on the same side (the apex is often recurved); cf. scorpioid.
words.name: helicoid

words.def: a vascular plant that does not develop a woody stem; e.g. a violet.
words.name: herb

words.def: not woody; usually green, and soft in texture.
words.name: herbaceous

words.def: a collection of preserved, usually dried, plant material. Also a building in which such collections are stored.
words.name: herbarium

words.def: Synonym of bisexual.
words.name: hermaphrodite

words.def: having parts, especially leaves, that are distinctly different between the juvenile and adult stages.
words.name: heteroblastic

words.def: of 2 or more distinct morphologies (e.g. of different size and shape).
words.name: heteromorphic

words.def: the condition of a species having flowers with different style and stamen lengths, but with all the flowers of any one plant being identical. see:distyly
words.name: heterostyly

words.def: the scar on a seed coat where it separates from its stalk (funicle).
words.name: hilum

words.def: the fruit of a rose.
words.name: hip

words.def: horseshoe-shaped.
words.name: hippocrepiform

words.def: bearing coarse, rough, longish hairs. See Indumentum.
words.name: hirsute

words.def: having long erect rigid hairs or bristles, harsh to touch.
words.name: hispid

words.def: covered with a greyish to whitish layer of very short, closely interwoven hairs, giving a frosted appearance.
words.name: hoary

words.def: a type chosen by the author of a name; cf. a lectotype, which is chosen by a later author.
words.name: holotype

words.def: perianth not divided into calyx and corolla. Compare to dichlamydeous, in which they are separate
words.name: homochlamydeous

words.def:
(never capiltalised) of gardens, an author citation used in two ways:
as a name misapplied by gardeners
words.name: hort.

words.def: translucent; usually delicately membranous and colourless.
words.name: hyaline

words.def: a plant produced by the crossing of parents belonging to two different named groups, e.g. genera, species, varieties, subspecies, forma and so on; i.e. the progeny resulting within and between two different plants. An F1 hybrid is the primary product of such a cross. An F2 hybrid is a plant arising from a cross between two F1 hybrids (or from the self-pollination of an F1 hybrid).
words.name: hybrid

words.def: the names of the parents of a hybrid joined by a multiplication sign, e.g. Cytisus ardonoi × C. purgans.
words.name: hybrid formula

words.def: a form of pollination whereby pollen is distributed by the flow of waters.
words.name: Hydrophily

words.def: A tube or cup-like structure in a flower that includes the bases of sepals, petals, and stamens, and may or may not be connected (adnate) to the ovary.
words.name: hypanthium

words.def: 1.  In botany, describing leaves or flowers that are in the usual position, but are borne on a petiole or pedicel, respectively, that is twisted 360 degrees. The term is used to describe organs, such as orchid flowers, that are usually resupinate. compare: #resupinate
words.name: hyper-resupinate

words.def: an enlarged fleshy structure that forms below the fruit, from the receptacle or hypanthium.
words.name: hypocarpium

words.def: of an embryo or seedling, the part of the plant axis below the cotyledon and node, but above the root. It marks the transition from root to stem development.
words.name: hypocotyl

words.def: salverform.
words.name: hypocrateriform

words.def: borne below the ovary; used to describe floral parts inserted below the ovary's level of insertion; cf. epigynous, perigynous.
words.name: hypogynous

words.def: The hypothallus is the outgrowth of hyphae from under the margin of the thallus of a crustose lichens, connecting the island-like areoles into a single lichen.
words.name: hypothallus

words.def: new leaves appear after flowering. See also proteranthous and synanthous
words.name: hysteranthous (histeranthous)

words.def: a cell, especially of a leaf, differing markedly from surrounding cells. They often synthesise specialised products such as crystals.
words.name: idioblast

words.def: a name not abiding by the rules of the botanical Codes, e.g. later homonyms, cultivars that have been Latinised after 1 Jan 1959; cultivar names with more than 10 syllables or 30 letters; cultivar names that use confusing names of other plants, e.g. Camellia 'Rose'.
words.name: illegitimate name (nomen illeg.)

words.def: overlapping each other; of perianth parts, edges overlapping in the bud (the convoluted arrangement is a special form of imbrication).
words.name: imbricate

words.def: a pinnate leaf with an odd number of pinnae (terminated by a single leaflet); compare paripinnate.
words.name: imparipinnate

words.def: in nomenclature, where the preceding author published the name in an article or book, authored or edited by the succeeding author.
words.name: in

words.def: The suffix added to the stem of a generic name to form the name of a subtribe: for instance, Corydalinae from Corydalis + -inae.
words.name: -inae

words.def: the production of offspring between closely related parents leading to a high degree of similarity; self-fertilization is the most intense form of inbreeding.
words.name: inbreeding

words.def: of unknown taxonomic affinity, relationships obscure.
words.name: incertae sedis

words.def: cut deeply and (usually) unevenly (a condition intermediate between toothed and lobed).
words.name: incised

words.def: enclosed, not protruding; for example stamens within the corolla.
words.name: included

words.def: bent or curved inwards; of leaf margins, when curved towards the adaxial side.
words.name: incurved

words.def: abbreviation of Latin inedita, an unpublished work. Used to indicate that a botanical name appeared only in a manuscript that was not published, so the name is invalid.
words.name: ined.

words.def: variable in number; numerous; e.g. more than twice as many stamens as petals or sepals, or when an inflorescence is not terminated by a flower (and continues growing); cf. definite.
words.name: indefinite

words.def: not opening in any definite manner at maturity; usually referring to fruit. Contrast with dehiscent.
words.name: indehiscent

words.def: unlimited, usually in growth.
words.name: indeterminate

words.def: native to the area, not introduced, and not necessarily confined to the region discussed or present throughout it (hardly distinct from ‘native’ but usually applied to a smaller area). For example, the Cootamundra Wattle is native to Australia but indigenous to the Cootamundra region of southern New South Wales; cf. endemic.
words.name: indigenous

words.def: a collective term for a surface covering of any kind of trichomes, e.g. hairs, scales.
words.name: indumentum

words.def: folded upwards, or folded with the two adaxial surfaces together.
words.name: induplicate

words.def: 1.  a membrane covering the sporangia of some ferns.
words.name: indusium

words.def: of an ovary, at least partly below the level of attachment of other floral parts; compare superior.
words.name: inferior

words.def: swollen, like a bladder.
words.name: inflated

words.def: bent sharply upwards or forwards; compare deflexed.
words.name: inflexed

words.def: several flowers closely grouped together to form an efficient structured unit; the grouping or arrangement of flowers on a plant.
words.name: inflorescence

words.def: denotes taxonomic ranks below species level, for example subspecies.
words.name: infraspecific

words.def: denoting taxonomic ranks below the genus level, for example, subgenera, sections, and series.
words.name: infrageneric

words.def: the grouping or arrangement of fruits on a plant.
words.name: infructescence

words.def: funnel-shaped, for example in the corolla of a flower.
words.name: wikt:infundibular (infundibuliform)

words.def: rolled inwards.
words.name: inrolled

words.def: catching, and drawing nutriment from, insects.
words.name: insectivorous

words.def: the point at which one organ or structure (such as a leaf) is joined to the structure which bears it (such as a stem).
words.name: insertion, point of

words.def: growing out from
words.name: inserted

words.def: in general, any covering, but especially the covering of an ovule.
words.name: integument

words.def: (e.g. of growth) occurring between the apex and the base of an organ
words.name: intercalary

words.def: a meristem located between the apex and the base of an organ
words.name: intercalary meristem

words.def: in pinnate leaves, glands occurring along the leaf rachis between the pinnae (occurring below the single, and often slightly larger, gland at or just below the insertion of the pinnae); cf. jugary.
words.name: interjugary glands

words.def: the portion of a stem between two nodes.
words.name: internode

words.def: of stipules, between the petioles of opposite leaves, e.g in Rubiaceae.
words.name: interpetiolar

words.def: inside but close to the margin, for example a vein in a leaf.
words.name: intramarginal

words.def: inside the stamens or androecium, usually referring to the location of a nectary disk.
words.name: intrastaminal

words.def: of anther locules, with opening towards the centre of flower (at least in bud); cf. extrorse, latrorse.
words.name: introrse

words.def: use of names not validly published according to the Code; i.e. they are not strictly 'names' in the sense of the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature.
words.name: invalid

words.def: A structure surrounding or supporting, usually a head of flowers. In Asteraceae, it is the group of phyllaries (bracts) surrounding the inflorescence before opening, then supporting the cup-like receptacle on which the head of flowers sits. In Euphorbiaceae it is the cuplike structure that holds the nectar glands, nectar, and head of flowers, and sits above the bract-like cyathophyll structure. Involucres occur in Marchantiophyta, Cycads, fungi, and many other groups.
words.name: involucre

words.def: rolled inwards, for example when the margins of a leaf are rolled towards the adaxial (usually upper) surface; compare revolute.
words.name: involute

words.def: with a reflective coloured sheen produced by structural coloration, as in the speculum of the mirror orchid Ophrys speculum.
words.name: iridescent

words.def: cannot be divided into two equal halves through any vertical plane. See also asymmetrical, compare zygomorphic, actinomorphic, regular.
words.name: irregular

words.def: A warty of club-like structure in some lichens that breaks off and forms new lichens without sexual reproduction. Isidia are dispersed by mechanical means, compared to soredia, which are dispersed by wind.
words.name: isidium

words.def: (of flat structures, especially leaves) with both surfaces similar, usually referring to cell types or to the number and distribution of stomata.
words.name: isobifacial

words.def: Having an equal number of parts in the whorls.
words.name: isomerous

words.def: having branches of equal diameter, compare to anisotomic.
words.name: isotomic

words.def: a node or junction of two parts; articulation.
words.name: joint

words.def: of glands, gland occurring on the rachis of a bipinnate leaf at the junction or attachment of pairs of pinnae or pinnules, as in some Acacia species; cf. interjugary.
words.name: jugary

words.def: formed on a young plant and different in form from the adult leaves.
words.name: juvenile leaves

words.def: In lichenology, "K" is the abbreviation for the outcome of a test in which a 10% solution of potassium hydroxide (KOH — hence "K") is placed on lichen tissues. Color change is noted by "K-" for none, and K+ for a yellow to red or purple color.
words.name: K, K+, K-

words.def: (adj. keeled), a prominent longitudinal ridge like the keel of a boat, e.g. the structure of the corolla formed by the fusion of the lower edge of the two abaxial anterior petals of a flower in the Fabaceae.
words.name: keel

words.def: see drupe.
words.name: kernel

words.def: a novel phenotypic trait that allows subsequent evolutionary radiation and success of a taxonomic group.
words.name: key innovation

words.def: the highest generally employed category of the taxonomic hierarchy, above that of division (phylum). The Plant Kingdom includes vascular plants, bryophytes and green algae and is also known as the clade Viridiplantae.
words.name: kingdom

words.def: lip; one of three or five petals which is (usually) different from the others, e.g. in Orchidaceae and Stylidiaceae.
words.name: labellum

words.def: lipped; where a corolla is divided into two parts, called an upper and lower lip, the two resembling an open mouth with lips.
words.name: labiate

words.def: jagged, as if torn.
words.name: lacerate

words.def: In foliose lichens, a linear to elongate lobe, usually arising from or at the end of a larger lobe
words.name: lacinia

words.def: Of lobes - with ends irregularly divided into deeply divided, narrow, pointed segments; Of margins - deeply divided into pointed segments in an irregular manner.
words.name: laciniate

words.def: An empty space, hole, cavity, pit, depression, or discontinuity.
words.name: lacuna

words.def: a thin, plate-like layer. (plural lamellae; adjective lamellate - composed of an assemblage of many layers)
words.name: lamella

words.def: the blade of a leaf or the expanded upper part of a petal, sepal or bract.
words.name: lamina

words.def: of, or pertaining to, the upper surface, such as the cortex of a lichen.
words.name: laminal

words.def: longer than broad, narrowly ovate, broadest in the lower half and tapering to the tip, like a lance or spear head; (sometimes, and incorrectly, used to mean narrowly elliptic).
words.name: lanceolate

words.def: attached to the side of an organ, e.g. leaves on a stem.
words.name: lateral

words.def: a milky fluid that exudes from such plants such as spurges, figs and dandelions.
words.name: latex

words.def: latex-bearing, producing a milky juice.
words.name: laticiferous

words.def: a type of anther dehiscence in which the anthers open laterally toward adjacent anthers. cf. introrse, extrorse.
words.name: latrorse

words.def: resembling Laurus, the laurel genus, particularly its leaves.
words.name: lauroid

words.def: loose, not compact. Of bundles of hyphae in lichens - not stiff and not adglutinate.
words.name: lax

words.def: an outgrowth of a stem, usually flat and green; its main function is food manufacture by photosynthesis. Abbreviation: lvs.
words.name: leaf

words.def: a parenchymatous area in the stele above (distal to) a leaf trace.
words.name: leaf gap

words.def: a healing layer forming on the stem where the leaf has fallen off.
words.name: leaf scar

words.def: a vascular bundle connecting the stele to a leaf.
words.name: leaf trace

words.def: the ultimate segments of a compound leaf.
words.name: leaflets

words.def: of lichens, having apothecia with rims of tissue similar to the tissue of the thallus, as in the genus Lecanora[3]
words.name: lecanorine

words.def: 1.  a fruit characteristic of the family Fabaceae, formed from one carpel and either dehiscent along both sides, or indehiscent.
words.name: legume

words.def: the lower of 2 bracts enclosing a grass flower.
words.name: lemma

words.def: Typically lens-shaped (lenticular) porous tissue in bark with large intercellular spaces that allows direct exchange of gases between the internal tissues and atmosphere through the bark.
words.name: lenticel

words.def: 1.  lens-shaped.
words.name: lenticular

words.def: covered with small scales.
words.name: lepidote

words.def: powdery
words.name: leprose

words.def: a woody climbing plant, rooted in the ground (liane is also used).
words.name: liana

words.def: a woody climbing plant, rooted in the ground. See also liana.
words.name: liane

words.def: growing on or in lichens, often but not necessarily as parasites
words.name: lichenicolous

words.def: woody
words.name: ligneous

words.def: Dead wood, typically in the context of a substrate for lichens.
words.name: lignum

words.def: Growing on wood tissue after bark as fallen or been stripped off (compare to corticolous)
words.name: lignicolous
