words.def: a woody swelling of the stem below or just above the ground; contains adventitious buds from which new shoots can develop, e.g. after fire.
words.name: lignotuber

words.def: 1.  bearing a ligule.
words.name: ligulate

words.def: 1.  small membranous appendage on the top of the sheath of grass leaves.
words.name: ligule

words.def: various pre-metric units somewhat larger than 2 mm, used in botany into the 20th century. See Line (unit) and Paris line.
words.name: linea, line, British line, Paris line

words.def: very narrow in relation to its length, with the sides mostly parallel. See Leaf shape.
words.name: linear

words.def: a plant growing on rocks; an epilithic plant.
words.name: lithophytic

words.def: part of a leaf (or other organ), often rounded, formed by incisions to about halfway to the midrib.
words.name: lobe

words.def: of a fruit, when it dehisces through the centres of loculi; cf. septicidal.
words.name: loculicidal

words.def: a chamber or cavity containing seeds within an ovary, pollen within an anther or spores in a sporangium.
words.name: locule

words.def: one of 2 or three minute organs at the base of the ovary of a grass flower, representing parts of a strongly reduced perianth.
words.name: lodicule

words.def: a pod-like indehiscent fruit that develops constrictions between the segments and at maturity breaks into one-seeded segments.
words.name: lomentum

words.def: (anthers) opening lengthwise by longitudinal slits. compare: poricidal
words.name: longicidal

words.def: crescent-shaped.
words.name: lunate

words.def: lyre-shaped; deeply lobed, with a large terminal lobe and smaller lateral ones.
words.name: lyrate

words.def: spotted, marked with spots.
words.name: maculate

words.def: a biogeographic region comprising Malaysia, Indonesia, New Guinea, and the Philippines.
words.name: Malesia

words.def: growth habit in which several woody stems arise separately from a lignotuber; a plant with such a growth habit, e.g. many Eucalyptus species; vegetation characterized by such plants.
words.name: mallee

words.def: a shrub or small tree growing in salt or brackish water, usually characterized by pneumatophores. Tropical coastal vegetation characterized by such species.
words.name: mangrove

words.def: the edge, as in the edge of a leaf blade.
words.name: margin

words.def: occurring at or very close to the margin.
words.name: marginal

words.def: a waterlogged area; swamp.
words.name: marsh

words.def: edible fruit and nuts produced by woody species of plants, i.e. acorns and beechmast, that wildlife species and some domestic animals consume.
words.name: mast

words.def: covered with coarse, floury powder.
words.name: mealy

words.def: 1.  In a lichen, the typically undifferentiated tissue underneath the cortex of the thallus, or between the upper and lower cortex if both are present. The medulla is analogous to the tissues underneath the epidermis (skin) of a leaf. The uppermost region commonly contains most of the photobionts.
words.name: medulla

words.def: the larger of two kinds of spores produced by a heterosporous plant giving rise to the female gametophyte; compare microspore.
words.name: megaspore

words.def: the larger of two kinds of cones or strobili produced by gymnosperms, being female and producing the seeds; compare microstrobilus.
words.name: megastrobilus

words.def: thin, translucent and flexible, seldom green.
words.name: membranous

words.def: one segment of a fruit (a schizocarp) that splits at maturity into units derived from the individual carpels, or a carpel, usually 1-seeded, released by the break-up at maturity of a fruit formed from 2 or more joined carpels.
words.name: mericarp

words.def: an actively dividing tissue.
words.name: meristem

words.def: moist, avoiding both extremes of drought and wet; pertaining to conditions of moderate moisture or water supply; applied to organisms (vegetation) occupying moist habitats.
words.name: mesic

words.def: the fleshy portion of the wall of a succulent fruit inside the skin and outside the stony layer (if any), surrounding the seed(s); sarcocarp.
words.name: mesocarp

words.def: soft and with little fibrous tissue, but not succulent.
words.name: mesomorphic

words.def: 1.  mesophyll tissue, photosynthetic tissue of a leaf, the central tissues between the upper and lower epidermis.
words.name: mesophyll

words.def: (of vegetation) of moist habitats and having mostly large and soft leaves.
words.name: mesophyllous

words.def: a plant thriving under intermediate environmental conditions of moderate moisture and temperature, without major seasonal fluctuations.
words.name: mesophyte

words.def: the smaller of two kinds of spores produced by a heterosporous plant; compare megaspore.
words.name: microspore

words.def: the smaller of two kinds of cones or strobili produced by gymnosperms, being male and producing the pollen; compare megastrobilus.
words.name: microstrobilus

words.def: the central, and usually most prominent, vein of a leaf or leaf-like organ; midvein.
words.name: midrib

words.def: see midrib.
words.name: midvein

words.def: a single individual that is free from other individuals, not united with them into a group. The term is usually used for pollen to distinguish single grains from tetrads or polyads.
words.name: monad

words.def: resembling a string of beads.
words.name: moniliform

words.def: flowering and setting seed only once before dying. See also semelparous, semelparity
words.name: monocarpic

words.def: a cymose inflorescence with the branches arising singly; cf. dichasium.
words.name: monochasium

words.def: abbreviation of monocotyledons.
words.name: monocots

words.def: a flowering plant whose embryo has one cotyledon (seed leaf); compare dicotyledon.
words.name: monocotyledon

words.def: of vascular plants, hermaphrodite, with all flowers bisexual; or with male and female reproductive structures in separate flowers but on the same plant; or of an inflorescence that has unisexual flowers of both sexes; cf. dioecious.
words.name: monoecious

words.def: of bryophyte gametophytes, hermaphrodite, bisexual, when both male and female reproductive structures develop on the same individual. cf. dioicous.
words.name: monoicous

words.def: of a group of plants, a comprehensive treatise presenting an analysis and synthesis of taxonomic knowledge of that taxon; the fullest account possible (at the time) of a family, tribe or genus. It is generally worldwide in scope and evaluates all taxonomic treatments of that taxon including studies of its evolutionary relationships with other related taxa, and cytological, genetic, morphological, palaeobotanical and ecological studies. The term is often incorrectly applied to any systematic work devoted to a single taxon. Compare revision.
words.name: monograph

words.def: of one type, rather than several. See also dimorphic (two types) and polymorphic (many types)
words.name: monomorphic

words.def: Having a single leaf.
words.name: monophyllous

words.def: a mode of stem growth and branching in which the main axis is formed by a single dominant meristem.
words.name: monopodial

words.def: Being a single cell thick, as in the alga Monostroma.
words.name: monostromatic

words.def: containing only one taxon of the next lower rank, e.g. a family with only one genus, or a genus that includes only a single species.
words.name: monotypic

words.def: the shape or form of an organism or part thereof.
words.name: morphology

words.def: Diminutive: mucronule. A sharp, short point, generally at the tip of a leaf or the tip of the midrib of a compound leaf.[4]
words.name: mucro

words.def: terminating in a mucro.
words.name: mucronate

words.def: a cluster of fruits produced from more than one flower and appearing as a single fruit, often on a swollen axis, as in Moraceae; cf. aggregate fruit.
words.name: multiple fruit

words.def: covered with short hard protuberances.
words.name: muricate

words.def: an abrupt and inexplicable variation from the norm, such as the doubleness in flowers, changes in colour, or habit of growth.
words.name: mutation

words.def: The fungal component of a lichen (compare to photobiont.
words.name: mycobiont

words.def: The "vegetative" (nonreproductive) part of a fungus, mostly composed of aggregations of hyphae. It functions in substrate decomposition and absorption of nutrients.
words.name: mycelium

words.def: The fungal component of a lichen (compare to photobiont.
words.name: mycobiont

words.def: one of several types of symbiotic association between a fungus and the roots of a plant.
words.name: mycorrhiza

words.def: a plant that obtains most or all of its carbon, water and nutrients by associating with a fungus.
words.name: mycotroph

words.def: naturally occurring in an area, but not necessarily confined to it; cf. endemic.
words.name: native

words.def: a hybrid taxon produced by chance in the wild.
words.name: natural hybrid

words.def: describing a plant, introduced from another region, that grows and reproduces readily in competition with the natural flora.
words.name: naturalised

words.def: a (usually sweet) fluid produced by the flowers of many plants, collected by bees and other insects.
words.name: nectar

words.def: (adjective nectariferous) a specialized gland that secretes nectar.
words.name: nectary

words.def: a plant that was recently introduced to a geographic area; cf. archaeophyte.
words.name: neophyte

words.def: synonym of vein.
words.name: nerve

words.def: the part of a stem where leaves or branches arise.
words.name: node

words.def: (Latin) a conserved name, usually a name that became so much better known than the correct name, that a substitution was made.
words.name: nomen conservandum

words.def: (Latin), a name that is either superfluous at its time of publication because the taxon to which it was applied already has a name, or the name has already been applied to another plant (a homonym).
words.name: nomen illegitimum

words.def: (Latin, see valid publication) a name that is not validly published, and technically is therefore not a botanical name. (Abbreviation: nom. inval.)
words.name: nomen invalidum

words.def: (Latin) a name not published in accordance with the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants, usually without a diagnosis or description of the entity to which it applies, and without reference to either; such a name should not be used.
words.name: nomen nudum

words.def: the naming of things; often restricted to the correct use of scientific names in taxonomy; a system that sets out provisions for the formation and use of names.
words.name: nomenclature

words.def: of plants, containing harmful or unwholesome qualities. Applied in conjunction with 'weed' to specifically describe a plant which legislation deems harmful to the environment. Each state and territory in Australia has specific legislation governing noxious weeds.
words.name: noxious

words.def: the tissue of the ovule of a seed plant that surrounds the female gametophyte. It is enclosed by integuments and is not of epidermal origin.
words.name: nucellus

words.def: Stamens are described as numerous when there are more than twice as many as sepals or petals, especially when there is no set number of them.
words.name: numerous

words.def: a hard, dry, indehiscent fruit, containing only one seed.
words.name: nut

words.def: a small nut, one of the lobes or sections of the mature ovary of some members of the Boraginaceae, Verbenaceae, and Lamiaceae.
words.name: nutlet

words.def: inversely; usually same shape as suffix but attached by the narrower end, for example obcordate, oblanceolate, obovate.
words.name: ob-

words.def: of a fruit, hypanthium, pistil or calyx structure; an inverted cone shape, attached at apex.
words.name: obconic

words.def: of a leaf blade, broad and notched at the tip; heart shaped but attached at the pointed end.
words.name: obcordate

words.def: stamens arranged in two whorls, and having twice as many as the petals, the outer whorl being opposite the petals. Compare: diplostemonous.
words.name: obdiplostemonous

words.def: a 2-dimensional shape, lanceolate but broadest in the upper third.
words.name: oblanceolate

words.def: of parasites, unable to survive without the host; compare faculative.
words.name: obligate

words.def: slanting; of a leaf or stem, larger on one side of the midrib than the other, in other words asymmetrical.
words.name: oblique

words.def: length a few times greater than width, with sides almost parallel and ends rounded.
words.name: oblong

words.def: of a leaf, a 2-dimensional shape of which the length is about 1.5 times the width, and widest above the centre.
words.name: obovate

words.def: not evident, or at most rudimentary or vestigial.
words.name: obsolete

words.def: blunt or rounded; converging edges making an angle of more than 90°; compare acute. See Leaf shape.
words.name: obtuse

words.def: a sheath, formed from two stipules, encircling the node in Polygonaceae.
words.name: ocrea (ochrea)

words.def: (imparipinnate) having an odd number of leaflets in a compound leaf.
words.name: odd-pinnate

words.def: often. Compare usu. and s.t.
words.name: oft.

words.def: The suffix added to the stem of a generic name to form the name of a subfamily: for instance, Fumaria → Fumarioideae.
words.name: -oideae

words.def: formerly, e.g., "olim B", formerly in the Berlin herbarium (Herbarium Berolinense).
words.name: olim

words.def: the sequence of developmental stages through which an organism passes.
words.name: ontogeny

words.def: listed after the botanical name of a plant, or the name of a publication, this indicates that a publication is listed in the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants as a suppressed work. Botanical names of the specified rank in the publication are considered not validly published (article 34).
words.name: opera utique oppressa (plural), and opus utique oppressum (singular)

words.def: a lid or cover that becomes detached at maturity, e.g. in Eucalyptus, a cap covering the bud and formed by the fusion or cohesion of perianth parts.
words.name: operculum (calyptra)

words.def: (as adjective) leaves or flowers borne at the same level but on opposite sides of the axis; or when something occurs on the same radius as something else, for example anthers opposite sepals; compare alternate.
words.name: opposite

words.def: flat and more or less circular.
words.name: orbicular

words.def: a group of one or more families sharing common features, ancestry, or both.
words.name: order

words.def: the original single parent plant from which a clone ultimately derives.
words.name: ortet

words.def: when an ovule is erect, with the micropyle directed away from the placenta; atropous; cf. amphitropous, anatropous, campylotropous.
words.name: orthotropous

words.def: see elliptical.
words.name: oval

words.def: the basal portion of a carpel or group of fused carpels, enclosing the ovule(s).
words.name: ovary

words.def: shaped like a section through the long-axis of an egg and attached by the wider end.
words.name: ovate

words.def: egg-shaped, with wider portion at base; 3-dimensional object, ovate in all sections through long-axis.
words.name: ovoid

words.def: loosely, the seed before fertilization; a structure in a seed plant within which one or more megaspores are formed (after fertilization it develops into a seed).
words.name: ovule

words.def: with a disproportionately thick trunk
words.name: pachycaul

words.def: with disproportionately thick stems
words.name: pachycladous

words.def:
(plural paleae)
1. the upper of two bracts enclosing a grass flower, major contributors to chaff in harvested grain.
words.name: palea

words.def: bearing paleae or chaffy scales, as in description of the receptacle of a capitulum of a plant in the Asteraceae.
words.name: paleate

words.def: Chaff-like in texture.
words.name: paleaceous

words.def: 1.  leaf with veins radiating out from a central point (usually at the top of a petiole), resembling spread out fingers pointing away from the palm.
words.name: palmate

words.def: deeply divided into several lobes arising from more or less the same level.
words.name: palmatifid

words.def: intermediate between palmate and palmatifid, i.e. the segments are not fully separated at the base; often more or less digitate.
words.name: palmatisect

words.def: (adjective paniculate) a compound raceme; an indeterminate inflorescence in which the flowers are borne on branches of the main axis or on further branches of these.
words.name: panicle

words.def: butterfly-like; with a corolla like that of a pea.
words.name: papilionate

words.def: (plural papillae, adjective papillose, papillate) a small, elongated protuberance on the surface of an organ, usually an extension of one epidermal cell.
words.name: papilla

words.def: in daisy florets, a tuft or ring of hairs or scales borne above the ovary and outside the corolla (representing the reduced calyx); a tuft of hairs on a fruit.
words.name: pappus

words.def: Also paraperigone. Anomalous secondary outgrowth of the perianthal meristem with ramifying vasculature. See also perigonium, perianth and corona
words.name: paraperigonium

words.def: an organism living on or in a different organism, from which it derives nourishment; compare saprophyte, epiphyte.
words.name: parasite

words.def: a versatile ground tissue composed of living primary cells that performs a wide variety of structural and biochemical functions in plants.
words.name: parenchyma

words.def: attached to the marginal walls of a structure, for example ovules attached to placentas on the wall of the ovary. See Placentation.
words.name: parietal

words.def: having an even number of leaflets (or pinnae), that is terminated by a pair of pinnae as opposed to a single pinna; compare imparipinnate.
words.name: paripinnate

words.def: the development or production of fruit without fertilization. compare stenospermocarpy.
words.name: parthenocarpy

words.def: Spreading, erect, standing at 90o to the axis. See also erecto-patent, patulous.
words.name: patent

words.def: patent.
words.name: patulous

words.def: having few flowers per inflorescence. See also pluriflor and uniflor.
words.name: pauciflor

words.def: pinnately divided with narrow segments closely set like the teeth of a comb.
words.name: pectinate

words.def: with a terminal lobe or leaflet, and on either side of it an axis curving outwards and backwards, bearing lobe or leaflets on the outer side of the curve.
words.name: pedate

words.def: (adjective pedicellate) the stalk of a flower. May be applied to the stalk of a capitulum in Asteraceae
words.name: pedicel

words.def: (adjective pedunculate) the stalk of an inflorescence.
words.name: peduncle

words.def: shield-like; with stalk attached to the lower surface and not to the margin.
words.name: peltate

words.def: transmitting light; for example, said of tiny gland dots in the leaves of e.g. Myrtaceae and Rutaceae that are visible when held in front of a light.
words.name: pellucid

words.def: hanging, for example an ovule attached to a placenta on the top of the ovary; compare suspended.
words.name: pendulous

words.def: tufted like an artist's brush; with long hairs towards one end.
words.name: penicillate

words.def: with pinnately arranged veins.
words.name: penninervation (penninerved)

words.def: in five parts, particularly with respect to flowers, five parts in each whorl. See also trimerous and tetramerous.
words.name: pentamerous

words.def: type of berry formed from an inferior ovary and containing many seeds, usually large with a tough outer skin, for instance, pumpkin, cucumber.
words.name: pepo

words.def: of an organ that survives vegetatively from season to season. A period of reduced activity between seasons is usual.
words.name: perennating

words.def: a plant whose life span extends over several years.
words.name: perennial

words.def: of a flower, when bisexual.
words.name: perfect

words.def: with its base wrapped around the stem (so that the stem appears to pass through it), e.g. of leaves and bracts.
words.name: perfoliate

words.def: with many holes. Used to describe the texture of pollen exine, and also to indicate that tracheary elements have a perforation plate. See also fenestrate.
words.name: perforate

words.def: in a tracheary element, part of the cell wall that is perforated; present in vessel members but not in tracheids. Should not be confused with a pit.
words.name: perforation plate

words.def: the collective terms for the calyx and corolla of a flower (generally used when the two are similar). Abbreviation: P. For instance P 3+3 indicates the calyx and corolla each have 3 elements, or 3 sepals + 3 petals
words.name: perianth

words.def: the wall of a fruit, developed from the ovary wall.
words.name: pericarp

words.def: Curved along parallel to a surface, cf. anticlinal.
words.name: periclinal

words.def: in flowering plants see perianth
words.name: perigonium

words.def: a sac around the pistillate flower of sedges
words.name: perigynium

words.def: borne around the ovary, i.e. of perianth segments and stamens arising from a cup-like or tubular extension of receptacle (free from the ovary but extending above its base); cf. epigynous, hypogynous.
words.name: perigynous

words.def: remaining attached to the plant beyond the usual time of falling, for instance sepals not falling after flowering, flower parts remaining through maturity of fruit; compare deciduous, caducous.
words.name: persistent

words.def: (adjective: perulate)
words.name: perule (lat. perula, perulae)

words.def: in a flower, one of the segments or divisions of the inner whorl of non-fertile parts surrounding the fertile organs, usually soft and conspicuously coloured; compare sepal.
words.name: petal

words.def: like a petal; soft in texture and coloured conspicuously.
words.name: petaloid

words.def: a leaf with a petiole. Compare sessile.
words.name: petiolate

words.def: the stalk of a leaf.
words.name: petiole

words.def: the stalk of a leaflet.
words.name: petiolule

words.def: Rock-dwelling; living on or among rocks.
words.name: petricolous

words.def: gymnosperms and angiosperms; plants producing stamens and gynoecia; literally plants with conspicuous sexual reproductive organs; cf. cryptogams.
words.name: phanerogam

words.def: the study of the timing of seasonal biological phenomena, such as flowering, leaf emergence, fruit ripening and leaf fall.
words.name: phenology

words.def: a specialised conducting tissue in vascular plants that transports sucrose from the leaves to other plant organs.
words.name: phloem

words.def: In a lichen, the component that does the photosynthesis, the green algae (Chlorophyta) or blue-green algae (Cyanobacteria). (compare to mycobiont, the fungal component.) Also called the phycobiont.
words.name: photobiont

words.def: the process by which sugars are made from carbon dioxide and water in cells containing chloroplasts.
words.name: photosynthesis

words.def: In a lichen, a synonym for photobiont
words.name: phycobiont

words.def: A leaf-like extension of the stem in Bryophytes
words.name: phyllid

words.def: (adjective phyllodineous) a leaf with the blade much reduced or absent, and in which the petiole and or rachis perform the functions of the whole leaf; e.g. many acacias; cf. cladode.
words.name: phyllode

words.def: (in ferns) a short outgrowth of the stem on which the frond is borne and that remains attached to the rhizome after the frond has been shed.
words.name: phyllopodium

words.def: the above-ground surface of plants as a habitat for epiphytic microorganisms.
words.name: phyllosphere

words.def: also phytomelanin. A black, inert, organic material that forms a crust-like covering of some seeds, commonly found in Asparagales, Asteraceae, etc. Adjective=phytomelanous
words.name: phytomelan

words.def: covered with soft, weak, thin and clearly separated hairs, which are usually defined as long and sometimes ascending.
words.name: pilose

words.def: (plural pinnae) a primary segment of a compound leaf.
words.name: pinna

words.def: a compound leaf with leaflets arranged on each side of a common petiole or axis; also applied to how the lateral veins are arranged in relation to the main vein.
words.name: pinnate

words.def: pinnately lobed.
words.name: pinnatifid

words.def: pinnately divided almost to midrib but segments still confluent.
words.name: pinnatisect

words.def: ultimate free division (or leaflet) of a compound leaf, or a pinnate subdivision of a multipinnate leaf.
words.name: pinnule

words.def: 1.  a single carpel when the carpels are free.
words.name: pistil

words.def: a flower containing pistils but no stamens
words.name: pistillate flower

words.def: in tracheary elements, a section of the cell wall where the secondary wall is missing, and the primary wall is present. Pits generally occur in pairs and link two cells.
words.name: pit

words.def: the central region of a stem, inside the vascular cylinder; the spongy parenchymatous central tissue in some stems and roots.
words.name: pith

words.def: the tissue within an ovary to which the ovules are attached.
words.name: placenta

words.def: the arrangement of ovules inside ovary; for example axile, free-central, parietal, marginal, basal, or apical.
words.name: placentation

words.def: The form of a lichen thalus which radiates outward with the ends of the radiating arms peeling up from the substrate, but which lack a cortex on the underside (unlike foliose lichens).
words.name: placodioid

words.def: these rights, governed by Plant Breeder's Rights Acts give the plant breeder legal protection over the propagation of a cultivar, and the exclusive rights to produce and to sell it, including the right to license others to produce and sell plants and reproductive material of a registered, deliberately bred variety. Cf. UPOV.
words.name: Plant Breeders Rights (PBR)

words.def: governed by the Plant Variety Rights the registration of new varieties is now governed by Plant Breeders Rights.
words.name: Plant Variety Rights (PVR)

words.def: the time between successive leaf initiation events.
words.name: Plastochron

words.def: pleated; folded back and forth longitudinally like a fan, such as the leaves of many palm species. The concept often appears in specific names in forms such as Aloe plicatilis and Acacia plicata. Commonly such names are not correctly appropriate, but are applied to distichous structures rather than plicate.
words.name: plicate

words.def: (of leaves) a suffix indicating that the main nerves are lateral and arise from a point distinctly above the base of the leaf. Combined with a numerical prefix to form words like 3-plinerved, 5-plinerved, and so on. Such leaves are especially characteristic of the family Melastomataceae.
words.name: -plinerved

words.def: like a feather; with fine hairs branching from a main axis.
words.name: plumose

words.def: the part of an embryo that gives rise to the shoot system of a plant; cf. radicle.
words.name: plumule

words.def: having many flowers per inflorescence. See also pauciflor and uniflor.
words.name: pluriflor

words.def: having many ovules as in placentae, carpels or ovaries.
words.name: pluriovulate

words.def: a vertical, aerial (at low tide) appendage to the roots of some plants, through which gases are exchanged; e.g. on mangroves.
words.name: pneumatophore

words.def: 1.  a legume, the fruit of a leguminous plant, a dry fruit of a single carpel, splitting along two sutures.
words.name: pod

words.def: powdery mass shed from anthers (of angiosperms) or microsporangia (of gymnosperms); the microspores of seed plants; pollen-grains.
words.name: pollen

words.def: pollen-grains cohering by a waxy texture or fine threads into a single body; pollinium; e.g. in orchids.
words.name: pollen-mass

words.def: the tissue in the style of a flower through which the pollen tubes grow.
words.name: pollen transmitting tissue

words.def: the transfer of pollen from the male organ (anther) to the receptive region of a female organ (stigma).
words.name: pollination

words.def: see pollen-mass.
words.name: pollinium

words.def: having bisexual and male flowers on some plants and bisexual and female flowers on others; cf. androdioecious, andromonoecious, dioecious, monoecious, polygamomonoecious, polygamous.
words.name: polygamodioecious

words.def: having male, female and bisexual flowers on the same plant; cf. androdioecious, andromonoecious, polygamodioecious, polygamous.
words.name: polygamomonoecious

words.def: having bisexual and unisexual flowers on the same plant.
words.name: polygamous

words.def: of several different kinds (in respect to shape and/or size), hence polymorphism. See also monomorphic (a single type) and dimorphic (two types)
words.name: polymorphic

words.def: with more than two of the basic sets of chromosomes in the nucleus; any sporophyte with cells containing three or more complete sets of chromosomes. Various combinations of words or numbers with '-ploid' indicate the number of haploid sets of chromosomes; e.g. triploid = 3 sets, tetraploid = 4 sets, pentaploid = 5 sets, hexaploid = 6 sets, and so on.
words.name: polyploid

words.def: having numerous stamens; the number of stamens being at least twice the number of sepals or petals, but not strictly three or four times that number.
words.name: polystemonous

words.def: a fruit that has developed partly from the ovary wall but mostly from the hypanthium, e.g., apple.
words.name: pome

words.def: 1.  all individuals of one or more species within a prescribed area.
words.name: population

words.def: opening by pores, like the capsule of a poppy, or like the anthers in several families of plants. compare: longicidal
words.name: poricidal

words.def: positioned behind, towards the rear, proximal; compare anterior, distal.
words.name: posterior

words.def: (adjective: prickly) hard, pointed outgrowth from the surface of a plant (involving several layers of cells but not containing a vein); sharp outgrowth from the bark, detachable without tearing wood; cf. thorn.
words.name: prickle

words.def: In lichens, a species reproducing mainly by sexual reproduction, not vegetative reproduction.
words.name: primary species

words.def: (venation) the single vein or array of veins that are conspicuously larger than any others in the leaf. In pinnate venation, the single primary vein is in the middle of the leaf. In palmate venation, several such veins radiate from a point at or near the base of the leaf.
words.name: primary vein

words.def: In lichens, a part of the thallus that has both fungal and algal parts and can break off for vegetative reproduction, e.g., an isidium, phyllidium, phyllocladium, or soredium).
words.name: propagule

words.def: a leaf formed at the base of a shoot, usually smaller than those formed later.
words.name: prophyll

words.def: (Latin) in part; in nomenclature, to denote that the preceding taxon includes more than one currently recognized entity, and that only one of those entities is being considered.
words.name: pro parte

words.def: spreading along the ground but not rooting at the nodes: not as close to ground as prostrate.
words.name: procumbent

words.def: a structure capable of producing a new plant; includes seeds, spores, bulbils, etc.
words.name: propagules

words.def: lying flat on the ground.
words.name: prostrate

words.def: male sex organs maturing before the female ones, e.g. a flower shedding pollen before the stigma is receptive; cf. protogynous.
words.name: protandrous

words.def: new leaves appear before flowers. See also hysteranthous and synanthous
words.name: proteranthous

words.def: a #gametophyte plant, usually flattened and delicate; e.g. in ferns and fern allies.
words.name: prothallus

words.def: female sex organs maturing before the male ones, e.g. a flower shedding pollen after the stigma has ceased to be receptive; cf. protandrous.
words.name: protogynous

words.def: near the point of origin or attachment, cf. distal.
words.name: proximal

words.def: covered with a powdery, waxy material; with a bloom.
words.name: pruinose

words.def: a particular form of inflorescence occurring in the Asteraceae and Euphorbiaceae, in which multiple flowers are grouped together to form a flower-like structure, commonly called a head or capitulum.
words.name: pseudanthium

words.def: false; not genuine; e.g. pseudo-bulb = a thickened, bulb-like internode in orchids, or a corm.
words.name: pseudo

words.def: an enlarged, persistent axillary bud scale that resembles a stipule; common in Bignoniaceae.
words.name: pseudostipule

words.def: having the appearance of being whorled (verticillate), without actually being so.
words.name: pseudoverticillate

words.def: covered with minute soft erect hairs.
words.name: puberulous (puberulent)

words.def: downy; covered with short, soft, erect hairs.
words.name: pubescent

words.def: having powdery or crumbly particles as if pulverized.
words.name: pulverulent

words.def: with a pulvinus
words.name: pulvinate

words.def: a swelling at either end of a petiole of a leaf or petiolule of a leaflet, e.g. in Fabaceae, that permits leaf movement.
words.name: pulvinus

words.def: marked with dots.
words.name: punctate

words.def: dot-like
words.name: punctiform

words.def: having a sharp hard point.
words.name: pungent

words.def: A blister-like swelling.
words.name: pustule

words.def: Having pustules.
words.name: pustulate

words.def: of a plant's form, tetrahedral, pyramid-shaped.
words.name: pyramidal

words.def: the stone of a drupe, consisting of the seed surrounded by the hardened endocarp.
words.name: pyrene

words.def: pear-shaped; a term for solid shapes that are broadest in the upper third and abruptly narrowed near the base.
words.name: pyriform

words.def: more or less square.
words.name: quadrate

words.def: (adjective racemose) an indeterminate inflorescence in which the main axis produces a series of flowers on lateral stalks, the oldest at the base and the youngest at the top; cf. spike.
words.name: raceme

words.def: the axis of a grass spikelet, above the glumes.
words.name: rachilla (rhachilla)

words.def: (plural rachises; rachides) the axis of an inflorescence or a pinnate leaf; for example ferns; secondary rachis is the axis of a pinna in a bipinnate leaf distal to and including the lowermost pedicel attachment.
words.name: rachis

words.def: with structures radiating from a central point as spokes on a wheel, for example, the lateral spines of a cactus.
words.name: radial

words.def: of daisies, of a capitulum, with ray florets surrounding disc florets.
words.name: radiate

words.def: springing from the root; clustered at base of stem.
words.name: radical

words.def: the part of an embryo giving rise to the root system of a plant; cf. plumule.
words.name: radicle

words.def: a moist temperate or tropical forest dominated by broad-leaved trees that form a continuous canopy.
words.name: rainforest

words.def: an individual member of a clone.
words.name: ramet

words.def: the axis of a flower, in other words, floral axis; torus; for example in Asteraceae, the floral base or receptacle is the expanded tip of the peduncle on which the flowers are inserted.
words.name: receptacle

words.def: bent or curved backwards or downwards.
words.name: recurved

words.def: folded outwards, or with the two abaxial surfaces together.
words.name: reduplicate

words.def: bent sharply back or down.
words.name: reflexed

words.def: a cultivar name accepted by the relevant International Cultivar Registration Authority.
words.name: registered name

words.def: 1.  the act of recording a new cultivar name with an International Cultivar Registration Authority.
words.name: registration

words.def: see actinomorphic.
words.name: regular

words.def: kidney-shaped.
words.name: reniform

words.def: 1.  In botany, describing leaves or flowers that are in an inverted position because the petiole or pedicel, respectively, is twisted 180 degrees. compare: #hyper-resupinate
words.name: resupinate

words.def: forming a network (or reticulum), e.g. veins that join one another at more than one point.
words.name: reticulate

words.def: bent backwards or downwards; cf. antrorse.
words.name: retrorse

words.def: with a blunt (obtuse) and slightly notched apex.
words.name: retuse

words.def: an account of a particular plant group, like an abbreviated or simplified monograph. Sometimes confined to the plants of a particular region. Similar to a monograph in clearly distinguishing the taxa and providing a means for their identification; compare monograph.
words.name: revision

words.def: rolled under (downwards or backwards), for example when the edges of leaves are rolled under towards the midrib; compare involute.
words.name: revolute

words.def: see rachis.
words.name: rhachis

words.def: The "root" or "trunk" projection of a foliose lichen that attaches the lichen to the substrate (what the lichen is growing on)
words.name: rhizine

words.def: the root epidermis, the outermost primary cell layer of the root
words.name: rhizodermis

words.def: a perennial underground stem usually growing horizontally. See also stolon. Abbreviation: rhiz.
words.name: rhizome

words.def: the below-ground surface of plants and adjacent soil as a habitat for microorganisms.
words.name: rhizosphere

words.def: like a rhombus: an oblique figure with four equal sides; compare trapeziform, trullate.
words.name: rhombic

words.def: a four-sided figure with opposite sides parallel but with adjacent sides an unequal length (like an oblique rectangle); see also rhombic.
words.name: rhomboid

words.def: a shape, for instance of a leaf, that is roughly diamond-shaped with length equal to width.
words.name: rhomboidal

words.def: with many cracks, as in the surface of a crustose areolate lichen.
words.name: rimose

words.def: a unit of a plant's axial system which is usually underground, does not bear leaves, tends to grow downwards, and is typically derived from the radicle of the embryo.
words.name: root

words.def: outgrowths of the outermost layer of cells just behind the root tips, functioning as water-absorbing organs.
words.name: root hairs

words.def: the dynamic community of microorganisms associated with plant roots.
words.name: root microbiome

words.def: 1. the part of a budded or grafted plant which supplies the root system, also simply called a stock.
words.name: rootstock

words.def: when parts are not whorled or opposite but appear so, due to the contractions of internodes, e.g. the petals in a double rose or a basal cluster of leaves (usually close to the ground) in some plants.
words.name: rosette

words.def: with a beak.
words.name: rostrate

words.def: circular and flattened; for example a corolla with a very short tube and spreading lobes (for instance some Solanaceae).
words.name: rotate

words.def: a plant that colonises or occupies disturbed waste ground. See also weed.
words.name: ruderal

words.def: poorly developed and not functional; compare vestigial.
words.name: rudimentary

words.def: wrinkled.
words.name: rugose

words.def: finely wrinkled.
words.name: rugulose

words.def: (usually applied to endosperm). irregularly grooved or ridged; appearing chewed. (a common type of endosperm in Myristicaceae).
words.name: ruminate

words.def: sharply pinnatifid or cleft, the segments directed downward.
words.name: runcinate

words.def: see stolon.
words.name: runners

words.def: rupestral, saxicolous, growing on or among rocks. (compare epilithic, lithophytic)
words.name: rupicolous

words.def: a plant belonging to the family Juncaceae or, more loosely, applied to various monocotyledons.
words.name: rush

words.def: pouched or shaped like a sack.
words.name: saccate

words.def: shaped like the head of an arrow; narrow and pointed but gradually enlarged at base into two straight lobes directed downwards; may refer only to the base of a leaf with such lobes; cf. hastate.
words.name: sagittate

words.def: trumpet-shaped; with a long, slender tube and a flat, abruptly expanded limb.
words.name: salverform

words.def: a dry, indehiscent fruit with its wall expanded into a wing, e.g. in the genus Acer.
words.name: samara

words.def: a common name given to various edible coastal plants, such as Salicornia spp. (Amaranthaceae), Crithmum maritimum (Apiaceae) and Limbarda crithmoides (Asteraceae).
words.name: samphire

words.def: (adjective saprophytic) an organism deriving its nourishment from decaying organic matter and usually lacking chlorophyll; compare parasite, epiphyte.
words.name: saprophyte

words.def: having long, slender, prostrate stolons (runners).
words.name: sarmentose

words.def: growing on stone, like some lichens.
words.name: saxicolous

words.def: rough to the touch with short hard emergences or hairs.
words.name: scabrid (scabrous)

words.def: ladderlike in structure or appearance.
words.name: scalariform

words.def: 1.  a reduced or rudimentary leaf, for example around a dormant bud.
words.name: scale

words.def: climbing, by whatever means. See also: scandent in Wiktionary.
words.name: scandent

words.def: (adjective scapose) a stem-like flowering stalk of a plant with radical leaves.
words.name: scape

words.def: having the floral axis more or less erect with a few leaves or devoid of leaves; consisting of a scape.
words.name: scapose

words.def: dry and membranous.
words.name: scarious

words.def: a dry fruit formed from more than one carpel but breaking apart into individual carpels (mericarps) when ripe.
words.name: schizocarp

words.def: the aerial part of a graft combination, induced by various means to unite with a compatible understock/rootstock.
words.name: scion

words.def: a cell with a thick, often lignified, cell wall that is shorter than a fiber cell and dies soon after the thickening of its cell wall.
words.name: sclereid

words.def: a strengthening or support tissue composed of sclereids or of a mixture of sclereids and fibers.
words.name: sclerenchyma

words.def: (adjective sclerophyllous) a plant with hard, stiff leaves; leaves stiffened with thick-walled cells.
words.name: sclerophyll

words.def: of a cymose inflorescence, when it branches alternately on one side and then the other; cf. helicoid.
words.name: scorpioid

words.def: with very small pits.
words.name: scrobiculate

words.def: dense vegetation dominated by shrubs.
words.name: scrubland

words.def: minute loose, membranous scales on the surface of some plant parts e.g. leaves.
words.name: scurf

words.def: chemicals produced by a plant that do not have a role in "primary" functions such as growth, development, photosynthesis, reproduction, etc.
words.name: secondary metabolite

words.def: In lichens, a "species" taxon of lichen reproducing only by vegetative means, whose components reproduce mainly by sexual means – cf. primary species.
words.name: secondary species

words.def: the tissues concerned with the secretion of gums, resins, oils and other substances in plants.
words.name: secretory tissue

words.def: the category of supplementary taxa intermediate in rank between subgenus and series. It is a singular noun always written with a capital initial letter, in combination with the generic name.
words.name: section (sectio)

words.def: with all the parts grouped on one side or turned to one side (applied especially to inflorescences).
words.name: secund

words.def: a plant belonging to the family Cyperaceae.
words.name: sedge

words.def: a ripened ovule, consisting of a protective coat enclosing an embryo and food reserves; a propagating organ formed in the sexual reproductive cycle of gymnosperms and angiosperms (together, the seed plants).
words.name: seed

words.def: part or subdivision of an organ, for example a petal is a segment of the corolla. A term sometimes used when the sepals and petals are indistinguishable.
words.name: segment

words.def: also called selfing, the acceptance by stigmas of pollen from the same flower or from flowers on the same plant, which means they are self-compatible.
words.name: self-pollination

words.def: When a plant flowers once then dies.
words.name: semelparity

words.def: (or semi-terete), rounded on one side, but flat on the other. See also terete
words.name: semiterete

words.def: a descriptive term for stigmas that, in response to touch, close the two lobes of the stigma together, ending the receptivity of the stigma, at least for the time that the lobes are closed together. Mimulus is perhaps the best-known example.
words.name: sensitive

words.def: in the sense of.
words.name: sensu

words.def: of a plant name, in its broadest sense.
words.name: sensu lato

words.def: of a plant name, in its narrowest sense.
words.name: sensu stricto

words.def: in a flower, one of the segments or divisions of the outer whorl of non-fertile parts surrounding the fertile organs, usually green; compare petal.
words.name: sepal

words.def: of a fruit, when it dehisces along the partitions between loculi; cf. loculicidal.
words.name: septicidal

words.def: (plural septa) a partition, for example the membranous wall separating the two valves of the pod of Brassicaceae.
words.name: septum

words.def: arranged in rows.
words.name: seriate

words.def: silky with dense appressed hairs.
words.name: sericeous

words.def: the category of supplementary taxa intermediate in rank between section and species. It is a plural adjective; for instance Primula subgenus Primula sect. Primula series Acaules.
words.name: series

words.def: toothed with asymmetrical teeth pointing forward; like the cutting edge of a saw.
words.name: serrate

words.def: finely serrate.
words.name: serrulate

words.def: attached without a stalk, e.g. of a leaf without a petiole or a stigma, when the style is absent.
words.name: sessile

words.def: (adjectives setose, setaceous) a bristle or stiff hair (in Bryophytes, the stalk of the sporophyte); a terminal seta is an appendage to the tip of an organ, e.g. the primary rachis of a bipinnate leaf in Acacia.
words.name: seta

words.def: a tubular or rolled part of an organ, e.g. the lower part of the leaf in most grasses.
words.name: sheath

words.def: usually the aerial part of a plant; a stem including its dependent parts, leaves flowers etc.
words.name: shoot

words.def: a woody perennial plant without a single main trunk, branching freely, and smaller than a tree.
words.name: shrub

words.def: shaped like the letter 'S'.
words.name: sigmoid

words.def: a stout siliqua (not more than twice as long as wide).
words.name: silicula

words.def: a dry, dehiscent fruit (more than twice as long as wide) formed from a superior ovary of two carpels, with two parietal placentas and divided into two loculi by a 'false' septum.
words.name: siliqua

words.def: densely covered with fine soft straight appressed hairs, with a lustrous sheen and satiny to the touch.
words.name: silky

words.def: the science of forestry and the cultivation of woodlands for commercial purposes and wildlife conservation.
words.name: silviculture

words.def: undivided, for instance a leaf not divided into leaflets (note, however, that a simple leaf may be entire, toothed or lobed) or an unbranched hair or inflorescence.
words.name: simple

words.def: with deep, wave-like depressions along the margins, but more or less flat; compare undulate.
words.name: sinuate

words.def: a notch or depression between two lobes or teeth in the margin of an organ.
words.name: sinus

words.def: single, of flowers that grow one plant per year, one in each axil, or widely separated on the plant; not grouped in an inflorescence.
words.name: solitary

words.def: In a lichen, the structure that bears soredium for non sexual reproduction.
words.name: soralia

words.def: plural of soredium
words.name: soredia

words.def: In a lichen, a small groups of algal cells surrounded by fungal filaments that form in soralia, which break off and grow new lichens without sexual reproduction after being dispersed by wind. Compare to an isidium, which breaks off and is dispersed by mechanical means.
words.name: soredium

words.def: abbreviation of species (singular), often used when the genus is known but the species has not been determined, as in Brassica sp.
words.name: sp.

words.def: abbreviation of species (plural). See sp.
words.name: spp.

words.def: a spicate (spike-like) inflorescence with a stout, often succulent axis.
words.name: spadix

words.def: (adj. spathaceous), a large bract ensheathing an inflorescence. Traditionally any broad flat blade.
words.name: spathe

words.def: spoon-shaped; broad at the tip with a narrowed projection extending to the base.
words.name: spathulate (spatulate)

words.def: a group, or populations of individuals, sharing common features and/or ancestry, generally the smallest group that can be readily and consistently recognized; often, a group of individuals capable of interbreeding and producing fertile offspring. The basic unit of classification, the category of taxa of the lowest principal rank in the nomenclatural hierarchy.
words.name: species

words.def: follows the name of the genus, and is the second word of a botanical binomial. The generic name and specific epithet together constitute the name of a species; i.e. the specific epithet is not the species name.
words.name: specific epithet

words.def: (adjective spicate) a spike.
words.name: spica

words.def: (adjective spicate) an unbranched, indeterminate inflorescence in which the flowers are without stalks; cf. raceme.
words.name: spike

words.def: a unit of the inflorescence especially in grasses, sedges and some other monocotyledons, consisting of one to many flowers and associated bracts (glumes).
words.name: spikelet

words.def: (adjective spinose) a stiff, sharp structure, formed by the modification of a plant organ that contains vascular tissue; e.g. a lateral branch or a stipule; includes thorns.
words.name: spine

words.def: ending in a spine; modified to form a spine.
words.name: spinescent

words.def: of arrangement, when plant parts are arranged in a succession of curves like the thread of a screw, or coiled in a cylindrical or conical manner.
words.name: spiral

words.def: A cup-like structure in cryptograms for spore dispersal whereby energy of raindrops hitting into the cup splash back out carrying the spore.[6]
words.name: splash-cup (sporangia)

words.def: a structure in which spores are formed.
words.name: sporangium (sporangia)

words.def: an organ bearing sporangia, e.g. in the cones of Equisetum.
words.name: sporangiophore

words.def: a haploid propagule, produced by meiosis in diploid cells of a sporophyte that can germinate to produce a multicellular gametophyte.
words.name: spore

words.def: a fruiting body containing spores.
words.name: sporocarp

words.def: a modified leaf that bears a sporangium or sporangia, in pteridophytes.
words.name: sporophyll

words.def: the haploid multicellular phase in the alternation of generations of plants and algae that produces the spores; cf. gametophyte.
words.name: sporophyte

words.def: a naturally occurring variant of a species, not usually present in a population or group of plants; a plant that has spontaneously mutated so that it differs from its parent plant.
words.name: sport

words.def: extending horizontally, for example branches; standing out at right angles to axis, for example leaves or hairs.
words.name: spreading

words.def: 1.  a short shoot.
words.name: spur

words.def: (plural squamules, squamulae) small scales; In lichens, squamules are overlapping plate-like forms, sometimes overlapping so much as to become leaf-like, but which lack a lower cortex, unlike the leafy forms of foliose lichens – adjective: squamulose
words.name: squamule

words.def: Covered with small scales (squamules). In lichens, being composed of squamules
words.name: squamulose

words.def: with tips of leaves, stems etc. radiating or projecting outwards as in the moss Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus.
words.name: squarrose

words.def: abbreviation for sometimes, compare usu. and oft.
words.name: s.t.

words.def: the supporting structure of an organ, usually narrower in diameter than the organ.
words.name: stalk

words.def: (adjective staminate) male organ of a flower, consisting (usually) of a stalk (filament) and a pollen-bearing portion (anther).
words.name: stamen

words.def: a flower with stamens but no pistil
words.name: staminate flower

words.def: a sterile stamen, often rudimentary, sometimes petal-like.
words.name: staminode

words.def: the large posterior petal of pea-flowers.
words.name: standard

words.def: a representative specimen of a cultivar (or other taxon), one that demonstrates how the name of that taxon should be used.
words.name: standard specimen

words.def: the primary vascular system (phloem, xylem and ground tissue) of plant stems and roots.
words.name: stele

words.def: star-shaped, for example a type of hair.
words.name: stellate

words.def: the plant axis, either aerial or subterranean, which bears nodes, leaves, branches and flowers.
words.name: stem

words.def: see amplexicaul.
words.name: stem-clasping

words.def: the development or production of fruit that is seedless or has minute seeds because of the abortion of seed development. compare parthenocarpy
words.name: stenospermocarpy

words.def: infertile, for example a stamen that does not bear pollen, or a flower that does not bear seed.
words.name: sterile

words.def: the pollen-receptive surface of a carpel or group of fused carpels, usually sticky; usually a point or small head at the summit of the style.
words.name: stigma

words.def: in ferns, the stalk of a frond; generally a small stalk.
words.name: stipe

words.def: (stipel; plural stipellae) one of two small secondary stipules at the base of leaflets in some species.
words.name: stipella

words.def: stalked; borne on a stipe; of an ovary, borne on a gynophore.
words.name: stipitate

words.def: bearing stipules.
words.name: stipulate

words.def: small appendage at the bases of leaves in many dicotyledons.
words.name: stipule

words.def: slender, prostrate or trailing stem, producing roots and sometimes erect shoots at its nodes. See also rhizome.
words.name: stolon

words.def: see rootstock.
words.name: stock

words.def: having stolons.
words.name: stoloniferous

words.def: (plural stomata) a pore; small hole in the surface of a leaf (or other aerial organ) allowing the exchange of gases between tissues and the atmosphere.
words.name: stoma

words.def: striped with parallel, longitudinal lines or ridges.
words.name: striate

words.def: covered with appressed, rigid, bristle-like, straight hairs; the appressed equivalent of hispid.
words.name: strigose

words.def: (plural strobili) a cone-like structure consisting of sporophylls (e.g. conifers and club mosses) or sporangiophores (e.g. in Equisetopsida) borne close together on an axis.
words.name: strobilus

words.def: an elongated part of a carpel, or group of fused carpels, between the ovary and the stigma.
words.name: style

words.def: an elongate stigma that resembles a style, a false style, e.g. commonly found in Poaceae and Asteraceae.
words.name: stylodium

words.def: the elongated apex of a free carpel which functions like the style of a syncarpous ovary, allowing pollen tubes from its stigma to enter the locule of only that carpel.
words.name: stylulus

words.def: the category of supplementary taxa intermediate between genus and section. It is a singular noun, always has a capital initial letter and is used in combination with the generic name; e.g. Primula subgenus Primula.
words.name: subgenus

words.def: Inflated, but less than spherical. See also globose.
words.name: subglobose

words.def: undershrub; small shrub which may have partially herbaceous stems, but generally a woody plant less than 1 m high.
words.name: subshrub

words.def: a grouping within a species, usually used for geographically isolated and morphologically distinct entities. Its taxonomic rank occurs between species and variety.
words.name: subspecies

words.def: to stand beneath or close to, as in a bract at the base of a flower.
words.name: subtend

words.def: not quite square; see also quadrangular in wiktionary.
words.name: subquadrangular

words.def: narrow and tapering gradually to a fine point.
words.name: subulate

words.def: juicy, fleshy; a plant with a fleshy habit.
words.name: succulent

words.def: a shoot of more or less subterranean origin; an erect shoot originating from a bud on a root or a rhizome, sometimes at some distance from the stem of the plant.
words.name: sucker

words.def: subshrub or undershrub.(plural suffrutices). See also suffrutex for etymology etc.
words.name: suffrutex

words.def: furrowed; grooved.
words.name: sulcate

words.def: on the surface.
words.name: superficial

words.def: of an ovary, borne above the level of attachment of the other floral parts, or above the base of a hypanthium; compare inferior, half-inferior.
words.name: superior

words.def: of an ovule, when attached slightly below the summit of the ovary; compare pendulous.
words.name: suspended

words.def: a junction or seam of union. (see fissure, commissure)
words.name: suture

words.def: extensive, more or less even cover of a surface, for example a lawn grass; compare tussock.
words.name: sward

words.def: with more or less similar or overlapping ranges of distribution.
words.name: sympatric

words.def: a mode of growth in which the main axis is repeatedly terminated, and replaced with a lateral branch. Examples occur in the family Combretaceae, including the genera Terminalia and Combretum
words.name: sympodial

words.def: a hollow infructescence containing multiple fruit, such as that of a fig.
words.name: syconium

words.def: with, together.
words.name: syn- (sym-)

words.def: capable of being divided into at least two equal, mirror-image halves (e.g. zygomorphic) or to have rotational symmetry (e.g. regular, actinomorphic). Contrast with irregular, asymmetrical.
words.name: symmetrical

words.def: with united (connate or fused) petals.
words.name: sympetalous

words.def: a fused aggregate of sporangia, e.g. in the trilocular (=with three chambers) sporangia of the whisk fern Psilotum.
words.name: synangium

words.def: new leaves and flowers appear and die back at the same time. See also hysteranthous and proteranthous
words.name: synanthous

words.def: The dispersal of diaspores as units, where each bears more than one seed, for example where each diaspore comprises an entire inflorescence, as in Brunsvigia or multi-seeded fruit as in Tribulus zeyheri. Ephemeral synaptospermy is the term for when the diaspores split into units containing fewer or single seeds each, as in most tumbleweeds. True synaptospermy is when the diaspore generally remains entire until germination, as commonly happens in species of Grielum.
words.name: synaptospermy

words.def: of a gynoecium, made up of united carpels.
words.name: syncarpous

words.def: outdated name or 'alternative' name for the same taxon.
words.name: synonym

words.def: Synonym of bisexual.
words.name: synoecious

words.def: the main, descending root of a plant with a single dominant root axis.
words.name: taproot

words.def: having a surface that is course, thick, rough, and crumbling.
words.name: tartareous

words.def: (plural taxa) a group or category in a system of classification, derived from the Greek prefixes taxo-, taxis- meaning arrangement.
words.name: taxon

words.def: the study of the principles and practice of classification.
words.name: taxonomy

words.def: the inner layer of the testa (seed coat). It develops from the inner integument of the ovule.
words.name: tegmen

words.def: a slender organ (modified e.g. from stem, leaf, leaflet or stipule) used by climbing plants to cling to an object.
words.name: tendril

words.def: perianth segment, either sepal or petal; usually used when all perianth segments are similar in appearance; cf. petal.
words.name: tepal

words.def: circular in cross-section; more or less cylindrical without grooves or ridges. Also semiterete.
words.name: terete

words.def: situated at the tip or apex.
words.name: terminal

words.def: in groups of three; of leaves, arranged in whorls of three; of a single leaf, with the leaflets arranged in groups of three. See Leaf shape.
words.name: ternate

words.def: generally denotes of or on the ground; of habitat, on land as opposed to in water (aquatic) or on rocks (lithophytic), or other plants (epiphytic), and so on.
words.name: terrestrial

words.def: seed coat.
words.name: testa

words.def: a group of four; usually means four pollen grains remaining fused together a maturity, e.g. in the Epacridaceae.[7]
words.name: tetrad

words.def: square, with four corners, four-angled, e.g. the cross section of the stems of herbaceous Lamiaceae.
words.name: tetragonal

words.def: in four parts, particularly with respect to flowers, four parts in each whorl. See also trimerous and pentamerous.
words.name: tetramerous

words.def: having four complete sets of chromosomes in each sporophyte cell.
words.name: tetraploid

words.def: the asexual spore of red algae. It is so named because each sporangium produces just four spores. See Rhodophyceae.[8]
words.name: tetraspore

words.def: obsolete. 1) see receptacle; 2) the inflorescence disk of Asteraceae; 3) as used by Carl Linnaeus, the calyx
words.name: thalamus

words.def: The "vegetative" part (part other than sexual fruitbodies) of a lichen that has both the fungus (mycobiont) and photobiont; plural thalli
words.name: thallus

words.def: one of the usually two synangia in which pollen is produced in flowering plants. It consists of two fused sporangia known as pollen sacs. The wall between the pollen sacs disintegrates before dehiscence, which is usually by a common slit.
words.name: theca

words.def: a sharp, stiff point, usually a modified stem, that cannot be detached without tearing the subtending tissue; a spine; cf. prickle.
words.name: thorn

words.def: the opening of a corolla or perianth.
words.name: throat

words.def: a branched inflorescence in which the main axis is indeterminate (racemose) and the lateral branches determinate (cymose).
words.name: thyrse

words.def: (adjective tomentose) a dense covering of short, matted hairs. Tomentose is often used as a general term for bearing an indumentum, but this is not a recommended use.
words.name: tomentum

words.def: with a more or less regularly incised margin.
words.name: toothed

words.def: see receptacle.
words.name: torus

words.def: see pollen transmitting tissue.
words.name: transmitting tissue

words.def: 1.  like a trapezium (a four-sided figure with two parallel sides of unequal length)
words.name: trapeziform

words.def: a woody plant, usually with a single distinct trunk and generally more than 2-3 m tall.
words.name: tree

words.def: a group of three.
words.name: triad

words.def: planar and with 3 sides.
words.name: triangular

words.def: a taxonomic grouping, in rank between genus and family.
words.name: tribe

words.def: in non-filamentous plants, any hair-like outgrowth from epidermis, e.g. a hair or bristle; sometimes restricted to unbranched epidermal outgrowths.
words.name: trichome

words.def: split into three parts. See also bifid.
words.name: trifid

words.def: a compound leaf of three leaflets, for example a clover leaf.
words.name: trifoliolate (or trifoliate)

words.def: triangular in cross-section and obtusely angled; cf. triquetrous.
words.name: trigonous

words.def: in three parts, particularly with respect to flowers, three parts in each whorl. See also tetramerous and pentamerous.
words.name: trimerous

words.def: having three nerves or veins.
words.name: trinerved

words.def: (of leaves) having three main nerves with the lateral nerves arising from the midnerve above the base of the leaf.
words.name: triplinerved

words.def: more or less triangular in cross-section, but acutely angled (with 3 distinct longitudinal ridges); cf. trigonous.
words.name: triquetrous

words.def: also trivalvar. Divided into three valves. See also bivalve
words.name: trivalve

words.def: the second word in the two-part scientific name of an organism; cf. specific epithet.
words.name: trivial name

words.def: a vegetative, nutrient-producing leaf or microphyll, whose primary function is photosynthesis. It is not specialized or modified for some other function. (compare: sporophyll).
words.name: trophophyll

words.def: ovate but angled; like a bricklayer's trowel; inverse kite-shaped; compare rhombic.
words.name: trullate

words.def: cut off squarely; with an abruptly transverse end.
words.name: truncate

words.def: the upright large main stem of a tree.
words.name: trunk

words.def: a compact cluster of flowers or fruits arising from one centre; for instance, evident in many rhododendrons.
words.name: truss

words.def: an underground storage organ formed by the swelling of an underground stem which produces buds and stores food, forming a seasonal perennating organ, for example potato; compare tuberoid.
words.name: tuber

words.def: a small wart-like outgrowth.
words.name: tubercle

words.def: covered in tubercles; warty.
words.name: tuberculate

words.def: an underground storage organ formed by the swelling of a root; occurs in many orchids.
words.name: tuberoid

words.def: resembling a tuber; producing tubers.
words.name: tuberous

words.def: with the form of a tube or cylinder.
words.name: tubular

words.def: densely fasciculate at the tip.
words.name: tufted

words.def: outer covering of some bulbs and corms, hence tunicate.
words.name: tunic

words.def: of bulbs, consisting of concentric coats.
words.name: tunicate

words.def: top-shaped.
words.name: turbinate

words.def: swollen with liquid; firm; compare flaccid.
words.name: turgid

words.def: a dense tuft of vegetation, usually well separated from neighbouring tussocks, for example some grasses; compare sward.
words.name: tussock

words.def: having leaves arranged in two rows in the same plane, on opposite sides of the branch; = distichous.
words.name: two-ranked

words.def: an item (usually a herbarium specimen) to which the name of a taxon is permanently attached, i.e. a designated representative of a plant name. Important in determining the priority of names available for a particular taxon.
words.name: type

words.def: in nomenclature, the genus from which the family is based.
words.name: type genus

words.def: the presentation of printed matter, covering issues such as type styles (e.g. italic or roman type), underlining, emboldening and letter spacing.
words.name: typography

words.def: (adjective umbellate) a racemose inflorescence in which all the individual flower stalks arise in a cluster at the top of the peduncle and are of about equal length; in a simple umbel, each stalk is unbranched and bears only one flower; a cymose umbel looks similar to an umbel but its flowers open centrifugally.
words.name: umbel

words.def: a rounded elevation, such as in the middle of the top of an umbrella or mushroom
words.name: umbo (mycology)

words.def: having an umbo, with a conical or blunt projection arising from a flatter surface, as on the top of a mushroom, or in the scale of a pine cone.
words.name: umbonate

words.def: hook shaped.
words.name: unciform

words.def: with a hook at the apex.
words.name: uncinate

words.def: a low shrub, often with flowering branches that die off in winter; cf. subshrub.
words.name: undershrub

words.def: plant life growing beneath the forest canopy.
words.name: understory

words.def: wavy and not flat; compare sinuate.
words.name: undulate

words.def: having a single flower (uniflory). Compare pauciflor (few) and pluriflor (many)
words.name: uniflor

words.def: having one loculus or chamber, e.g., the ovary in the families Proteaceae and Fabaceae.
words.name: unilocular

words.def: Arranged in a single row or series. Unbranched. Uniseriate.
words.name: uniserial

words.def: Arranged in a single row or series. Unbranched. Uniserial.
words.name: uniseriate

words.def: of one sex; bearing only male or only female reproductive organs, dioecious, dioicous. See Sexual reproduction in plants.
words.name: unisexual

words.def: (of an ovule), covered by a single integument.
words.name: unitegmic

words.def: literally means "shaped like an urn" (or pitcher), with a swollen middle and narrowing top. Examples of urceolate plant structures are the pitchers of many species of the pitcher plant genera Sarracenia and Nepenthes. Etymology: Mid-18th century, From Latin urceolus "little pitcher", urceus "pitcher".
words.name: urceolate

words.def: abbreviation for usually, compare s.t. and oft.
words.name: usu.

words.def: a small bladder; a membranous bladder-like sac enclosing an ovary or fruit; in sedges a fruit in which the pericarp is larger than, and loosely encloses, the seed.
words.name: utricle

words.def: a resin canal coinciding with a longitudinal groove in the seeds of Asteraceae. A longitudinal cavity in the cortex of the stems of Equisetum, coinciding with a groove in the stem surface.
words.name: vallecular canal

words.def: of sepals and petals in bud, which meet edge to edge but do not overlap.
words.name: valvate

words.def: a portion of an organ that fragments or splits open, for example the teeth-like portions of a pericarp in a split (dehisced) capsule or pod when ripe.
words.name: valve

words.def: see varietas.
words.name: var

words.def: a plant or group of plants showing some measure of difference from the characteristics associated with a particular taxon.
words.name: variant

words.def: (Latin) in the Linnean hierarchy a rank below that of species, between the ranks of subspecies and form.
words.name: varietas (variety in common usage, abbreviated as var.)

words.def: irregularly marked with blotches or patches of another colour.
words.name: variegated

words.def: an adjective referring to the conducting tissues, the (xylem and phloem), in vascular plants.
words.name: vascular

words.def: a bundle of vascular tissue in the primary stems of vascular plants, consisting of specialised conducting cells for the transport of water (xylem) and assimilate (phloem).
words.name: vascular bundle

words.def: Container used by botanists for collecting field specimens.
words.name: vasculum

words.def: a strand of vascular tissue, e.g. in vascular plant leaves; nerve.
words.name: vein

words.def: a small vein; the ultimate (visible) division of a vein.
words.name: veinlet

words.def: a spongy tissue covering the aerial roots of orchids and some other epiphytes.
words.name: velamen

words.def: densely covered with fine, short, soft, erect hairs.
words.name: velvety

words.def: the arrangement of veins in a leaf.
words.name: venation

words.def: the front; in particular, towards the axis (adaxial) in a lateral organ or towards the substrate in a prostrate plant; contrast dorsal, abaxial.
words.name: ventral

words.def: the arrangement of unexpanded leaves in a bud; the order of unfolding of leaves from a bud.
words.name: vernation

words.def: wart-like in form.
words.name: verruciform

words.def: with warts.
words.name: verrucose

words.def: minutely warty, minutely verrucose.
words.name: verruculose

words.def: of anthers, swinging freely about the point of attachment to the filament.
words.name: versatile

words.def: arranged in one or more whorls, i.e. several similar parts arranged at the same point of the axis. e.g. leaf arrangement. Hence pseudoverticillate, appearing whorled or verticillate but not so
words.name: verticillate

words.def: a type of pseudo-verticillate inflorescence, typical of Lamiaceae, in which pseudo-whorls are formed from pairs of opposite cymes.
words.name: verticillaster

words.def: of hairs, bladder-like; vesciculous, bearing such hairs.
words.name: vesicular

words.def: a capillary tube formed from a series of open-ended cells in the water-conducting tissue of a plant.
words.name: vessel

words.def: reduced in form and function from the normal or ancestral condition.
words.name: vestigial

words.def: Abounding in or covered with long, soft, straight hairs; shaggy with soft hairs.
words.name: villous

words.def: 1.  Vitis.
words.name: vine

words.def: Wand-shaped, twiggy, especially referring to erect, straight stems. Diminutive: virgulate. In mycology, referring to a pileus with radiating ribs or lines.
words.name: virgate

words.def: literally "green plants". A clade of autotrophic organisms that includes green algae, Charophyta and land plants, that have cellulose in their cell walls, chloroplasts derived from primary endosymbiosis with Cyanobacteria that contain chlorophylls a and b and lack phycobilins.
words.name: Viridiplantae

words.def: sticky; coated with a thick, syrupy secretion.
words.name: viscid

words.def: 1.  seeds or fruits which germinate before being shed from the parent plant.
words.name: viviparous

words.def: a surface covered with small round protuberances, especially in fruit, leaves, twigs and bark, see tuberculate.
words.name: warty

words.def: an erect strong-growing or epicormic shoot developing from near the base of a shrub or tree, but distinct from a sucker.
words.name: watershoot

words.def: 1.  a weed is loosely defined as a plant growing where it is not wanted; commonly associated with disrupted habitats. See also ruderal
words.name: weed

words.def: originating from a known wild habitat (wilderness). See Wildlife.
words.name: wild

words.def: a ring of organs borne at the same level on an axis, for example leaves, bracts or floral parts.
words.name: whorl

words.def: 1.  a membranous expansion of a fruit or seed which aids in dispersal, for instance on pine seeds.
words.name: wing

words.def: very densely covered with long, more or less matted or intertwined hairs, resembling sheep's wool.
words.name: woolly

words.def: a plant with structural features (e.g. hard or succulent leaves) or functional adaptations that prevent water loss by evaporation; usually associated with arid habitats, but not necessarily drought-tolerant; cf. xerophyte.
words.name: xeromorph

words.def: a plant generally living in a dry habitat, typically showing xeromorphic or succulent adaptation; a plant able to tolerate long periods of drought; cf. xeromorph.
words.name: xerophyte

words.def: a specialised water-conducting tissue in vascular plants.
words.name: xylem

words.def: having light and dark circular bands or rings.
words.name: zonate

words.def: bilaterally symmetrical; symmetrical about one vertical plane only; applies to flowers in which the perianth segments within each whorl vary in size and shape; compare actinomorphic, irregular.
words.name: zygomorphic

words.def: a fertilized cell, the product of fusion of two gametes.
words.name: zygote
